{"uri": "2024-07-416916051", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:12:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:12:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:10:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.kansas.com/sports/soccer/article289907454.html", "title": "Lionel Messi, Argentina roll past Canada into Copa America final", "body": "Argentina is one victory away from a triple crown when it plays for the Copa America title on Sunday after defeating Canada 2-0 in a semifinal on Tuesday in East Rutherford, N.J.\n\nA win in Miami Gardens, Fla., over Colombia or Uruguay -- their semifinal is Wednesday in Charlotte -- would add to Argentina's golden period. La Albiceleste captured the 2021 Copa America championship, then won the 2022 World Cup.\n\n\"It is crazy what this group has done, what the Argentine national team has been doing,\" said Lionel Messi, who scored his first goal of the tournament on Tuesday. \"After this, much more importance will be given to all the finals that I played and to all the players of the old generation.\n\n\"It is a difficult Copa, very hard, with a heavy temperature. The fact that we are once again in a final is to be highlighted. I am aware that these are the last battles, and I am enjoying them to the fullest.\"\n\nNo South American team has accomplished the treble, which would be similar to Spain's run from 2008 to 2012 of two European championships sandwiching the 2010 World Cup.\n\n\"I'm not really interested about it,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni said. \"The most important thing is to win, not what the statistics say that we could win three finals in a row.\".\n\nArgentina is pursuing its record 16th Copa America championship. Uruguay also has 15 titles.\n\nScaloni believes his players don't take winning for granted.\n\n\"Everyone thinks that it is very easy and straightforward, and Canada has shown today that it's not an easy task,\" he said. \"They were a very tough opponent and everyone is giving their best. But of course, we are very pleased, and I hope that everyone can enjoy this, the people and the players.\"\n\nMessi, who was hampered by a groin/thigh injury earlier in the tourney, looked reinvigorated on a hot and humid night playing on a sand-laden, natural-grass field.\n\nAfter Julian Alvarez scored in the 22nd minute, Messi made it 2-0 in the 51st minute when he used his left foot to redirect a shot by Enzo Fernandez. It wasn't a typical Messi goal, but it still counted as his 109th for his country and the 14th of his Copa America career.\n\nMessi had to wait a few minutes for a full celebration because the play was reviewed for him being offside, but Canadian defender Derek Cornelius had played him onside.\n\nEarlier, Messi brought the crowd of 80,102 to its feet in the 12th minute when he whipped a shot from the edge of the box a foot outside the right post.\n\nAlvarez, who scored the first goal of the tournament on June 20 in the 2-0 win over the Canadians, did it to them again after Argentina absorbed some early forays into its end by the lone remaining CONCACAF representative.\n\nRodrigo De Paul was near midfield when he sent a through ball forward. Alvarez, who plays for Manchester City, perfectly timed his run and with one touch pushed the ball ahead of the back line. He tracked the ball to score from the top of the box.\n\n\"It seems easy after everything we've been doing, but it's not,\" Alvarez said. \"We deserve it, we have been working very well.\"\n\nCanada's best chance to tie came two minutes into first-half stoppage time off a throw-in when Jonathan David tried to beat Emiliano Martinez at the near post but was denied.\n\nArgentina had the advantage in shots on goal (3-2) and shot attempts (11-9).\n\nCanada was a surprise semifinalist. The program was in disarray until Racine, Wis., native Jesse Marsch took over in May. He led the Canadians out of group stage in their first Copa America appearance when many predicted Mexico or the United States had the better chance to challenge for a title.\n\n\"The tournament caught up with us a little bit. ... In the end, we're still in the beginning of our process, right?\" Marsch said. \"Argentina has maybe had eight years together, seven years together with this team.\n\n\"I think in general, what I said to the team afterwards is: I know that they're very disappointed, but I'm very proud of them. You know, we've put together some incredible performances.\"\n\nThe Canadians will play the third-place match in Charlotte on Saturday against the Colombia-Uruguay loser.\n\n\"I took this job seven weeks ago,\" Marsch said. \"I couldn't have imagined that I'd be right here, right now, right? So, I'm really happy with the team and really happy with the progress.\"", "source": {"uri": "kansas.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Wichita Eagle"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8217964901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:04:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:04:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:04:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/lionel-messi-argentina-retirement-hint-33207030", "title": "Lionel Messi makes retirement admission as Argentina reach Copa America final", "body": "Lionel Messi was interviewed after the Copa America semi-finals\n\nLionel Messi admitted he knows that his days taking to the pitch as a professional footballer are winding down after helping Argentina reach another Copa America final. The legendary forward reflected on cherishing the final days of his international career with his teammates while he still can.\n\nArgentina clinched a 2-0 victory against Canada, with Julian Alvarez lighting up the scoreboard early in the first half and Messi sealing the deal in the 51st minute. During his post-match interview, Messi spoke about savoring each moment in the iconic Albiceleste jersey, acknowledging that his time on the pitch won't last forever.\n\n\"I am aware that these are the last few battles, that is why I am enjoying it very much,\" said Messi. \"Let's enjoy everything that we are living and enjoying as a national team. It is not easy to get to another final.\n\nREAD MORE: Lionel Messi leaves opponent looking foolish while doing what Cristiano Ronaldo couldn't\n\nREAD MORE: Man Utd star Lisandro Martinez left feeling unimpressed by Kylian Mbappe's comments\n\n\"We have to take advantage because it's not something easy These are some of my last battles and I have to enjoy.\"\n\nExpanding into further detail, Messi said, \"It's crazy what this group has been doing, what the Argentine National Team has been doing, because a lot of importance is being given to the finals that I and all of the old team played in. It's amazing that we're in a new final. It wasn't an easy cup: very tough teams, very bad pitches, the heat makes it very hard. It's worth enjoying being in a new final.\"\n\nMessi, who turned 37 last month, acknowledged that performing consistently is becoming increasingly difficult at this career stage. However, after returning to his teammates in the locker room, the Argentine hero shifted gears from reflection to motivation. Rallying his team, Messi excited the energy in the room and his teammates and declared: \"We still have one more step to go.\"\n\nArgentina will face Uruguay or Colombia in the Copa America final in Miami Gardens, Florida, on July 14. Albiceleste, which has clinched the title 15 times, is tied with Uruguay for the most victories in the competition's history. A win in the upcoming final would see Argentina emerge as the top nation in tournament history, solidifying their dominance in South American football.\n\nThe career of Messi with Argentina is decorated with multiple notable achievements. He helped lead his nation to glory as the 2022 FIFA World Cup champion, the 2021 Copa America winner, and the 2022 UEFA Cup of Champions winner with a 3-0 win over Mexico.\n\nMessi's legacy includes an Olympic gold medal from the 2008 Beijing Games. He once called the achievement his biggest: \"The Olympic gold in 2008 is the win that I value the most. He can stay with us as long as he wants, even when he retires \u2026 Let him decide what he wants,\u201d he said.\n\nMessi has chance to win a third straight major title with his national side following their 2022 World Cup triumph and their 2021 Copa America win.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d\u2019Or winner referenced veteran teammates Di Maria and Nicolas Otamendi and said success was validation for the difficult barren years the team had suffered.\n\n\u201cThe truth is that it\u2019s crazy what this group has done, what the Argentina national team has been doing, because after all this it gives value to all [the tournaments] I and the old generation have played in,\u201d Messi said.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s not easy for us to be in a final again, for us to compete again to be champions.\u201d\n\nDespite Argentina reaching the final with some comfort against Canada, the former Barcelona forward said it had been a tough test so far.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a difficult Copa, evenly matched, with very bad pitches, with high temperatures, very tough teams, and for us to be in a final again is something to enjoy,\u201d he said.\n\nGoalkeeper Emiliano Martinez said that despite being world champions the joy of reaching a final was just as intense as ever.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a source of pride as an Argentine, as a representative of this national team, to be able to play in another final. {"uri": "8218892122", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:31:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:31:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:30:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/lionel-messis-argentina-uses-kendrick-lamar-diss-track-to-mock-drake/articleshow/111639150.cms", "title": "Lionel Messi's Argentina uses Kendrick Lamar diss track to mock Drake | World News - Times of India", "body": "Drake a has history of being owned by short geniuses. After Kendrick Lamar (5'5''), it was his turn to be humbled by Lionel Messi, who's also known for his diminutive height but global stature.\n\nIn the Copa Am\u00e9rica semi-final, Messi scored the second goal for Argentina, leading them to a 2-0 victory over Canada and securing their place in Sunday's final, where they aim to retain the title, they won in 2021.The Canadian rapper had bet $300,000 on Canada winning, with the potential to earn $2.88 million.\n\nFollowing the match, Argentina's social media team posted a celebratory image of Messi and his teammates with the caption \"Not like us,\" referencing a diss track by Lamar aimed at Drake. This track, streamed nearly 500 million times on Spotify, marked a significant moment in their public feud, akin to a 7-0 thrashing by Lamar.\n\nWhile Lamar has not commented on Argentina's tactics under coach Lionel Scaloni, Messi has been mentioned in one of his songs. In \"The Hillbillies,\" a collaboration with his cousin Keem, the lyrics include: \"Critics sayin' that I lost the plot, principles, yeah, I'd rather not, Messi, 'bout to come in hot.\"\n\nLionel Messi scored as Argentina defeated Canada 2-0 to advance to the Copa America final, where they will seek their third consecutive major title. The 15-time Copa champions showcased their best performance of the tournament at MetLife Stadium, peaking at the right moment, much like their 2022 World Cup triumph. Messi, scoring his first goal of the tournament, expressed his joy at reaching another final and competing for the championship again.\n\nCanada, participating in their first Copa America, impressed by reaching the semi-finals but found Argentina too formidable. Coach Marsch noted his team's fatigue, which became evident midway through the first half. Despite an early chance for Jacob Shaffelburg, Argentina quickly took control.\n\nRodrigo De Paul set up the first goal in the 22nd minute, with Julian Alvarez finishing expertly. The trio of Di Maria, Messi, and De Paul continually troubled Canada's defense, with Di Maria creating several opportunities. Argentina doubled their lead early in the second half when De Paul assisted Enzo Fernandez, who set up Messi for the goal. Despite Canada's late efforts, Argentina comfortably held their lead, moving one win away from a record 16th Copa America title.\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. It is not easy to be in a final again, to compete again to be champions,\" Messi told TyC Sports.\n\n\"I'm living it as I have been living everything lately - enjoying it very much and being aware, as it happens to Fideo (Di Maria) and Ota (Nicolas Otamendi), that these are the last battles.\"\n\nArgentina boss Lionel Scaloni says he will work to \"convince\" Di Maria and Messi to continue with international duty.\n\n\"For Leo (Messi), it's similar to Angel,\" said Scaloni.\n\n\"We have to let him be and we will never be the ones to close the door. He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. Argentina.\n\nCanada, ranked 48th in the world, were knocked off their stride by Alvarez's goal and Argentina took a firmer grip on the game.\n\nLille striker Jonathan David had Canada's best chance in first-half stoppage time when he latched on to a long throw but his effort was fired straight at Aston Villa goalkeeper Emiliano Martinez.\n\nDespite the defeat, Canada surpassed expectations in their inaugural appearance at the Copa America.\n\nJesse Marsch's side, the co-hosts of the 2026 World Cup alongside Mexico and the USA, will face the losers from the other semi-final in a third-place play-off on Sunday.\n\n\"What I said to the team afterwards is I know that they're very disappointed, but I'm very proud of them,\" said Marsch.\n\n\"We've put together some incredible performances, We don't want to retire him earlier than needed. We don't want to feel melancholy. We have to let him play, and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us. But so far, he's here, and he has to be allowed to enjoy this moment,\" Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni told reporters.\n\nWhen asked about Messi's \"last battles\" comment, Scaloni said: \"We have to leave him alone, he knows that we will not be the ones to close the door on him. {"uri": "8218767569", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "13:15:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T13:15:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T13:14:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://kayhanlife.com/news/iran/soccer-argentinas-messi-surpasses-irans-daei-on-scoring-chart/", "title": "Soccer- Argentina's Messi Surpasses Iran's Daei on Scoring Chart - KAYHAN LIFE", "body": "EAST RUTHERFORD, New Jersey, July 9 (Reuters) - Defending champions Argentina booked their place in the Copa America final after goals from Julian Alvarez and Lionel Messi gave them a 2-0 win over Canada in Tuesday's semi-final in New Jersey.\n\nArgentina will face either Uruguay or Colombia in Sunday's final in Florida, a match that could represent the last shot at silverware for several senior squad members including Messi, Angel Di Maria and Nicolas Otamendi.\n\n\"Let's enjoy what we are experiencing as a national team, as a group. It is not easy to be in a final again, to compete again to be champions,\" Messi told TyC Sports.\n\n\"I'm living it as I have been living everything lately: enjoying it very much and being aware, as it happens to Fideo (Di Maria) and Ota (Otamendi), that these are the last battles.\"\n\nArgentina have won a joint-record 15 Copa titles and reached the final six times in the past eight editions but Canada caused them real problems in the opening 20 minutes, Jacob Shaffelburg twice shooting wide from promising positions.\n\nAfter soaking up the early pressure, though, Argentina went ahead when Rodrigo De Paul played through Alvarez, who ghosted in between two defenders to score with a tidy finish in the 22nd minute.\n\nCristiano Ronaldo Ties with Iran's Ali Daei as the All-Time Top Scorer in International Soccer\n\nCanada nearly snatched an equaliser against the run of play in first-half stoppage time as Jonathan David sneaked in ahead of his marker to get on the end of a long throw, but his close-range shot was hit straight at goalkeeper Emiliano Martinez.\n\nMessi had struggled with a muscle injury earlier in the tournament but appeared revitalised on a hot and humid evening at the MetLife Stadium.\n\nHe scored Argentina's second in the 51st minute, sticking out a boot to divert Enzo Fernandez's shot from the edge of the area past Canada goalkeeper Maxime Crepeau.\n\nThe goal moved Messi to joint fifth in the all-time Copa America scoring charts, level with Peru's Paolo Guerrero and Chile's Eduardo Vargas, on 14.\n\nHis 109th goal for Argentina also saw him surpass Iran's Ali Daei to take sole possession of second place on the all-time international scoring charts. Messi trails only Cristiano Ronaldo, who has scored 130 goals for Portugal.\n\nDespite their two-goal cushion, Argentina had a nervy finish to the match as Canada substitute Tani Oluwaseyi tested Martinez with a crisp shot in the 89th minute before directing a glancing header wide a minute later.\n\nFor Canada, the defeat ends a remarkable run in which they defied expectations and performed better than their higher-ranked CONCACAF rivals Mexico and the United States, their fellow co-hosts of the 2026 World Cup.\n\n\"They're the best team in the world, but at the same time we had our chances in the beginning of the game,\" midfielder Stephen Eustaquio told Canadian broadcaster TSN.\n\n\"If we scored one of our chances, the story of the game would probably have been different. very much and being aware.\"\n\nArgentina will face either Uruguay or Colombia in Sunday's final which will be held at the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida.\n\nCanada head coach Jesse Marsch told reporters before the semifinal that he was aware just how difficult it would be to play Argentina, but his side started well against the reigning world champion.\n\nCanada winger Jacob Shaffelburg, though, was made to rue two missed opportunities in the early stages as Argentina striker \u00c1lvarez opened the scoring with a composed touch and finish in the 22nd minute.\n\nThe goal was a sign of the quality that Canada, the world No. 48, was up against.\n\nMessi, possibly playing at his final Copa Am\u00e9rica for Argentina, then started finding his stride and went close twice into the second half as Enzo Fern\u00e1ndez's shot deflected off the Inter Miami forward, catching Canada goalkeeper Maxime Cr\u00e9peau off guard.\n\nCanada is now the 38th team that Lionel Messi has scored against while playing for his country, per Opta.\n\nDespite not reaching the final, Canada impressed at this year's tournament and showed promising signs for the upcoming World Cup in 2026, which it's co-hosting alongside Mexico and the US.\n\n\"[The tournament] has gone way better than any of us could have scripted,\" Marsch told reporters after the game.\n\n\"There is still a lot of He can stay with us as long as he wants, even when he retires...Let him decide what he wants,\" he said.\n\nMessi has chance to win a third straight major title with his national side following their 2022 World Cup triumph and their 2021 Copa America win.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or winner referenced veteran team-mates Di Maria and Nicolas Otamendi and said that the success was validation for the difficult barren years the team had suffered.\n\n\"The truth is that it's crazy what this group has done, what the Argentina national team has been doing, because after all this it gives value to all (the tournaments) I and the old generation have played in,\" Messi said on TyC Sports.\n\n\"It's not easy for us to be in a final again, for us to compete again to be champions,\" he added after the victory at MetLife Stadium.\n\nDespite Argentina reaching the final with some comfort against Canada, the former Barcelona forward said it had been a tough test so far.\n\n\"It's a difficult Copa, evenly matched, with very bad pitches, with high temperatures, very tough teams, and for us to be in a final again is something to enjoy,\" he said.\n\nGoalkeeper Emiliano Martinez said that despite being world champions the joy of reaching a final was just as intense as ever.\n\n\"It's a source of pride as an Argentine, as a representative of this national team, to be able to play in another final. Let's enjoy everything that we are living and enjoying as a national team. It is not easy to get to another final. We have to take advantage because it's not something easy These are some of my last battles and I have to enjoy,\" Messi was quoted by Mirror.\n\n\"It's crazy what this group has been doing, what the Argentine National Team has been doing, because a lot of importance is being given to the finals that I and all of the old team played in. It's amazing that we're in a new final. It wasn't an easy cup: very tough teams, very bad pitches, the heat makes it very hard. It's worth enjoying being in a new final,\" he added.\n\nMessi's career with Argentina is decorated with multiple notable achievements. The will play the final of the tournament July 14 at the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami against the winner of the Colombia-Uruguay match.\n\nCanada will play July 13 at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte against the loser of the aforementioned match.\n\nCanada and Argentina delivered a first half that began chaotically and was equally entertaining: without a midfield, and without the tension that defining matches usually have.\n\nThe first blow finally came in the 23rd minute with a goal from Alvarez, who received a good through ball from Rodrigo De Paul, shook off the marking and scored to break the tie.\n\nArgentina neutralised the Canadian attacks and created good scoring opportunities. At the end of the first half, Messi made a move in the area, and his shot went just past the goalkeeper's post.\n\nThe last chance of the first half was for Jonathan David, with Canada's first shot on goal in the match. At halftime, Argentina was ahead 1-0.\n\nAt the start of the second half, Messi cut in from the right as he used to do in his early days. {"uri": "8217949003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:45:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:45:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:45:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/lionel-messi-overtakes-ali-daei-to-become-the-second-all-time-top-goalscorer-in-mens-international-football-but-he-still-trails-cristiano-ronaldo-by-21-goals/", "title": "Lionel Messi overtakes Ali Daei to become the second all-time top goalscorer in men's international football - but he still trails Cristiano Ronaldo by 21 GOALS!", "body": "Lionel Messi broke a tie with Iran's Ali Daei to become the second all-time top scorer in men's international football with a goal against Canada in the Copa America semifinals.\n\nThe Argentine's 51st minute goal was his 109th for La Albiceleste. Aside from securing a chance to compete for their second straight Copa America title with a 2-0 win, Messi's scoring effort moved him one goal clear of the Iranian legend.\n\nHowever, Messi will have to score 21 more goals in international colors to overtake Cristiano Ronaldo's 130 for Portugal.\n\nMessi's scrappy effort from close range was his first goal for the 2023 Copa America and 14th overall in the tournament.\n\nBefore getting ahead, Messi tied Daei on the all-time scoring list with two goals in a 4-1 win over Guatemala in the eve of Copa America's kickoff in the United States.\n\nLionel Messi became the second-highest goalscorer in international football on Tuesday\n\nWith a goal against Canada in the Copa America semifinal, Messi broke his tie with Ali Daei\n\nAside from moving up in the goalscoring ranks, Messi broke another record in this year's tournament with an appearance milestone in their opening game.\n\nIn his 35th appearance across seven editions of the competition, the Inter Miami star broke a record that belonged to Chilean goalkeeper Sergio Livingstone since 1953. The future legend made his first tournament appearance in 2007.\n\nWith Messi still trailing the Portuguese star, India's Sunil Chhetri sits behind Daei with 93 goals for the Blue Tigers. Meanwhile, Mokhtar Dahari of Malaysia rounds up the top 5 with 89 goals.\n\nAcross men's and women's divisions, Canada's Christine Sinclair holds the all-time scoring record with 190 goals in 328 international appearances.\n\nMessi needs 21 more goals for Argentina to catch Cristiano Ronaldo's 130 goals for Portugal\n\nWith a 2-0 win, Messi helped his nation secure their second straight Copa America final berth\n\nMessi led Argentina to Copa America glory in 2021 before winning the World Cup in 2022\n\nAfter winning the Copa America in 2021, Messi led Argentina to winning the FIFA World Cup in Qatar the following year.\n\nHis record books now include 186 caps, 109 goals, and 56 assists for his nation.\n\nWhile bidding for his third trophy with the senior team, Messi also holds an The will play the final of the tournament on July 14 at the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami against the winner of the Colombia-Uruguay match.\n\nCanada will play on July 13 at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte against the loser of the aforementioned match.\n\nCanada and Argentina delivered a first half that began chaotically and was equally entertaining: without a midfield, and without the tension that defining matches usually have.\n\nThe first blow finally came in the 23rd minute with a goal from Alvarez, who received a good through ball from Rodrigo De Paul, shook off the marking and scored to break the tie.\n\nArgentina neutralised the Canadian attacks and created good scoring opportunities. At the end of the first half, Messi made a move in the area, and his shot went just past the goalkeeper's post.\n\nThe last chance of the first half was for Jonathan David, with Canada's first shot on goal in the match. At halftime, Argentina was ahead 1-0.\n\nAt the start of the second half, Messi cut in from the right as he used to do in his early days. Inside the box, he passed to Rodrigo de Paul, and after a rebound, Enzo Fernandez shot at the goal. Messi himself deflected it, and after a VAR review, it was confirmed as 2-0 for Argentina, marking Messi's first goal in this edition and his 14th in his Copa America career.\n\nWith that comfortable lead, Argentina slowed the game down and made substitutions to refresh the team. Di Maria also came off, in one of his last matches for the national team.\n\nWith two minutes remaining, Canada pressed Argentina's defense well and had their best chance, but Emilano Martinez managed {"uri": "8217934390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:29:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:29:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:28:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/argentina-see-off-canada-to-reach-copa-america-final/article_861454a8-758f-5ac2-b81d-5779d5da7cb5.html", "title": "Argentina see off Canada to reach Copa America final", "body": "Lionel Messi celebrates scoring Argentina's second goal in a 2-0 victory over Canada\n\nLionel Messi was on target as world champions Argentina turned on the style to beat Canada 2-0 on Tuesday and reach the Copa America final where they will look for a third straight major title.\n\nThe defending Copa champions will face the winners of Wednesday's semi-final between Uruguay and Colombia in what will be a highly anticipated final in Miami on Sunday.\n\nThe 15-times Copa champions produced their best display of the tournament in front of a capacity crowd at the 82,500 MetLife Stadium and as in their 2022 World Cup triumph they look to be peaking at the perfect moment.\n\n\"The truth is that it's crazy what this group has done, what the Argentina national team has been doing,\" Messi told TyC Sports after his first goal of the tournament.\n\n\"It's not easy for us to be in a final again, for us to compete again to be champions. I'm living it like I lived it in the last Copa America, in the last World Cup...These are the last battles and I'm enjoying them to the maximum,\" said the 37-year-old.\n\nCanada, who surprised many by reaching the last four in their first Copa America appearance, can take great credit for their run in the tournament but Messi and company were simply a step too far.\n\n\"I think the tournament caught up with us a little bit,\" said Canada's American coach Marsch, who said he noticed that his players looked tired midway through the first half.\n\n\"Eventually the physicality and fatigue can catch up with you and that was a big part of what happened with us tonight,\" he added.\n\nMarsch's side had progressed by hitting teams with high-energy football straight out of the gate but after an early opening for left-winger Jacob Shaffelburg, who fired wide after cutting in from the flank, the South Americans took control and never gave it up.\n\nAngel Di Maria, the veteran wide-man playing in his final tournament for his country, was seeing plenty of the ball down the right and he offered an early warning of his threat when he picked out Messi with a ball inside which the forward flashed just wife of the post.\n\nBut it was Rodrigo De Paul who was to create the breakthrough in the 22nd minute, picking the ball up on the half-way line, taking a quick glance up and then lofting the ball over the top to Julian Alvarez.\n\nThe Manchester City forward, recalled to the starting line-up ahead of Lautaro Martinez, delivered a deft first touch that took him away from Moises Bombito and gave him just enough room to drive the ball home.\n\nMore from this section DraftKings fined $100,000 by New Jersey gambling regulators over inaccurate data Flight Attendants Reveal Their Tips for Smart Packing and Flying 'I just want to win now': Raptors re-sign Barnes, Quickley - Classy triangle -\n\nThe classy triangle of Di Maria, Messi and De Paul, was a constant source of danger for Canada's back line and the former threatened a second with a chip from the right which floated over the bar.\n\nThe assuredness of Argentina's build-up play reflects the confidence of coach Lionel Scaloni's team, a well-drilled unit but one that never allows their organisational solidity dominate over their creativity.\n\nTwo minutes before the break, former Real Madrid winger Di Maria provided a slide-rule pass to Messi, who worked himself space for a shot on his right-foot, but he was narrowly wide of Max Crepeau's right-hand post.\n\nCanada's American coach Marsch had plenty of work to do at the interval if he was to find a way of getting his team back on level terms and any strategy went out of the window when the world champions doubled their lead, just six minutes after the restart.\n\nThe excellent De Paul pulled the ball back from the byline to Enzo Fernandez and his side-foot shot was directed home by Messi in front of goal.\n\nFor a moment Canada had hope that Messi may have been offside but the VAR review showed that defender Derek Cornelius had played him onside.\n\nThe two-goal cushion established, Argentina were content to sit back and preserve their energy and invite the Canadians to take them on.\n\nIt was not until the final minutes though that Canada were able to trouble Emiliano Martinez with substitute Tani Oluwaseyi forcing the keeper into action after some sloppy defending.\n\nBut it was a comfortable victory for Scaloni's men and one which leaves them one win away from a record 16th Copa America triumph.\n\nsev/rcw", "source": {"uri": Argentina beat Canada 2-0 to seal spot in Copa America final", "body": "Defending champions Argentina booked their place in the Copa America final after goals from Julian Alvarez and Lionel Messi gave them a 2-0 win over Canada in July 9th's semi-final in New Jersey.\n\nArgentina have won a joint-record 15 Copa titles and reached the final six times in the past eight editions but Canada caused them problems in the opening 20 minutes, with Jacob Shaffelburg twice shooting wide from promising positions.\n\nAfter soaking up the early pressure Argentina went ahead when Rodrigo De Paul played through Alvarez, who ghosted in between two defenders to score with a tidy finish in the 22nd minute.\n\n2022 World Cup winners Argentina gradually took control of the match and Messi had a chance to double their lead in the 44th minute as he created space in the box with silky footwork before lashing his effort wide.\n\nCanada nearly snatched an equaliser against the run of play in first-half stoppage time as Jonathan David sneaked in ahead of his marker to get on the end of a long throw, but his close-range shot was hit straight at goalkeeper Emiliano Martinez.\n\nMessi then scored Argentina's second in the 51st minute when he stuck out a boot to divert Enzo Fernandez's shot from the edge of the area past Canada goalkeeper Maxime Crepeau.\n\nThe goal moved Messi to joint fifth in the all-time Copa America scoring charts, level with Peru's Paolo Guerrero and Chile's Eduardo Vargas on 14.\n\nThe 37-year-old's 109th goal for Argentina also saw him surpass Iran's Ali Daei on the all-time international scoring charts. Messi is second behind Cristiano Ronaldo, who has scored 130 goals for Portugal.\n\nDespite their two-goal cushion, Argentina had a nervy finish to the match as Canada substitute Tani Oluwaseyi tested Martinez with a crisp shot in the 89th minute before directing a glancing header wide a minute later.\n\nArgentina will take on either Uruguay or Colombia, who meet on July 10, in the final in Florida goalscoring milestone in Argentina's Copa America triumph", "body": "Lionel Messi overtakes Ali Daei to become the second-highest men's international goalscorer of all time in Argentina's 2-0 Copa America semi-final win over Canada.\n\nyou have updates\n\nArgentina talisman Lionel Messi achieved another new goalscoring milestone as the reigning Copa America winners defeated Canada 2-0 to reach the final of this year's tournament in North America.\n\nThe Inter Miami forward had failed to find the mark in La Albiceleste's opening four games of the tournament, although he was benched for the final group fixture versus Peru amid concerns over his fitness.\n\nMessi subsequently played the full 90 against Ecuador in the last 16, as Argentina progressed in spite of the eight-time Ballon d'Or winner missing his penalty in the shootout, and he unsurprisingly kept his place in the first XI for the semi-final showdown with Canada.\n\nLionel Scaloni's men needed just 22 minutes to get off the mark at the MetLife Stadium, as Julian Alvarez latched onto Rodrigo de Paul's eye-of-the-needle pass and slotted home past Maxime Crepeau.\n\nWith six minutes played in the second period, the holders doubled their lead through captain Messi, although the 37-year-old's goal was not one of the most conventional he has scored in his career.\n\nMessi becomes second-highest male international scorer of all time\n\nChelsea midfielder Enzo Fernandez let fly from the edge of the area, and his strike was helped on its way into the back of the net via the studs of an onside Messi, who was credited with the goal.\n\nIn doing so, the ex-Paris Saint-Germain and Barcelona attacker scored for the 109th time for Argentina, seeing him overtake Iran's Ali Daei as the second-highest male goalscorer in international football history.\n\nMessi has surpassed Daei just a month on from matching his record of 108 in June's friendly win over Guatemala, although he is still some way off matching or breaking the all-time record set by Cristiano Ronaldo.\n\nMessi's long-time on-field rival has struck 130 times for Portugal, meaning that the Argentine needs another 21 goals for his nation to equal Ronaldo, who failed to find the back of the net once at Euro 2024 excluding penalty shootouts.\n\nHowever, both men are dwarfed by the feats of Canada's Christine Sinclair, who is the highest international scorer in men's or women's football with an astounding 190 goals in 328 matches.\n\nWill Messi break Ronaldo's all-time men's record?\n\nMany have expected Ronaldo to call time on his international career in the wake of a failed Euro 2024 campaign, but the 39-year-old has hinted that he wants to continue in the Portugal setup for a little while longer.\n\nWhether that will extend to an appearance at the 2026 World Cup remains to be seen, but Messi is expected to still be kicking by the time that tournament rolls around in what may be his international swansong.\n\nThe 37-year-old therefore still has ample time to draw closer to Ronaldo's 130 - unless the Al-Nassr forward postpones his international retirement and extends his record - but Messi admitted after the beating of Canada that his time is nearing an end too.\n\n\"I am aware that these are the last few battles, that is why I am enjoying it very much. Let's enjoy everything that we are living and enjoying as a national team. It is not easy to get to another final,\" Messi told the press after the game. \"We have to take advantage because it's not something easy These are some of my last battles and I have to enjoy.\"\n\nArgentina will face either Uruguay or Colombia in the 2024 Copa America final, which takes place on Saturday at the Hard Rock Stadium in Florida.\n\nbody check tags ::", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8218994426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "15:38:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T15:38:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T15:37:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.tv360nigeria.com/argentina-sees-off-canada-to-reach-copa-america-final/", "title": "Argentina sees off Canada to reach Copa America final - TV360 Nigeria", "body": "Lionel Messi was on target as world champions Argentina turned on the style to beat Canada 2-0 on Tuesday and reach the Copa America final where they will look for a third straight major title.\n\nThe defending Copa champions will face the winners of Wednesday's semi-final between Uruguay and Colombia in what will be a highly anticipated final in Miami on Sunday.\n\nThe 15-times Copa champions produced their best display of the tournament in front of a capacity crowd at the 82,500 MetLife Stadium and as in their 2022 World Cup triumph they look to be peaking at the perfect moment.\n\n\"The truth is that it's crazy what this group has done, what the Argentina national team has been doing,\" Messi told TyC Sports after his first goal of the tournament.\n\n\"It's not easy for us to be in a final again, for us to compete again to be champions. I'm living it like I lived it in the last Copa America, in the last World Cup...These are the last battles and I'm enjoying them to the maximum,\" said the 37-year-old.\n\nCanada, who surprised many by reaching the last four in their first Copa America appearance, can take great credit for their run in the tournament but Messi and company were simply a step too far.\n\n\"I think the tournament caught up with us a little bit,\" said Canada's American coach Marsch, who said he noticed that his players looked tired midway through the first half.\n\n\"Eventually the physicality and fatigue can catch up with you and that was a big part of what happened with us tonight,\" he added.\n\nMarsch's side had progressed by hitting teams with high-energy football straight out of the gate but after an early opening for left-winger Jacob Shaffelburg, who fired wide after cutting in from the flank, the South Americans took control and never gave it up.\n\nAngel Di Maria, the veteran wide-man playing in his final tournament for his country, was seeing plenty of the ball down the right and he offered an early warning of his threat when he picked out Messi with a ball inside which the forward flashed just wide of the post.\n\nBut it was Rodrigo De Paul who was to create the breakthrough in the 22nd minute, picking the ball up on the halfway line, taking a quick glance up and then lofting the ball over the top to Julian Alvarez.\n\nThe Manchester City forward recalled to the starting line-up ahead of Lautaro Martinez, delivered a deft first touch that took him away from Moises Bombito and gave him just enough room to drive the ball home.\n\n- Classy triangle -\n\nThe classy triangle of Di Maria, Messi and De Paul, was a constant source of danger for Canada's back line and the former threatened a second with a chip from the right which floated over the bar.\n\nThe assuredness of Argentina's build-up play reflects the confidence of coach Lionel Scaloni's team, a well-drilled unit but one that never allows their organisational solidity to dominate over their creativity.\n\nTwo minutes before the break, former Real Madrid winger Di Maria provided a slide-rule pass to Messi, who worked himself space for a shot on his right foot, but he was narrowly wide of Max Crepeau's right-hand post.\n\nCanada's American coach Marsch had plenty of work to do at the interval if he was to find a way of getting his team back on level terms and any strategy went out of the window when the world champions doubled their lead, just six minutes after the restart.\n\nThe excellent De Paul pulled the ball back from the byline to Enzo Fernandez and his side-foot shot was directed home by Messi in front of goal.\n\nFor a moment Canada had hope that Messi may have been offside but the VAR review showed that defender Derek Cornelius had played him onside.\n\nWith the two-goal cushion established, Argentina were content to sit back and preserve their energy and invite the Canadians to take them on.\n\nIt was not until the final minutes though that Canada were able to trouble Emiliano Martinez with substitute Tani Oluwaseyi forcing the keeper into action after some sloppy (AP) - Lionel Messi plans to keep playing for Argentina beyond Sunday's Copa America final.\n\n\"As I\u00b4ve said before, I intend to continue,\" he said Tuesday night after Argentina's 2-0 win over Canada. \"I intend to keep living day by day without thinking about what will come in the future or whether I\u00b4ll continue or not. It\u00b4s something I just live each day. I\u00b4m 37 years and only God knows when the end will be.\"\n\nMessi scored his 109th international goal, his first in this year's tournament. It was his 14th in Copa America play, three shy of the record.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d\u00b4Or winner spoke outside the locker room at MetLife Stadium, where he announced his retirement after missing a penalty kick in the shootout loss to Chile in the 2016 Copa America final. He reversed his decision seven weeks later and has scored 54 goals in 73 international appearances since, raising his matches for Argentina to 186 as he helped win the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.\n\nTeammate \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda does intend to retire after Sunday's game against Uruguay or Colombia at Miami Gardens, Florida. The 36-year-old Di Mar\u00eda made his international debut in 2008 and has 31 goals in 144 appearances,\n\n\"It\u00b4s my last battle. There's nothing left to say that I haven\u00b4t said a lot of times before,\" Di Mar\u00eda explained. \"It\u00b4s my last game. I have to say thank you to all Argentineans and to this generation that has allowed me to lift so many trophies.\"\n\nArgentina's Lionel Messi dribbles during a Copa America semifinal soccer match against Canada in East Rutherford, N.J., Tuesday, July 9, 2024. (AP Photo/Julia Nikhinson)\n\nDi Mar\u00eda joined with Messi to lead Argentina to it's third World Cup and 15th Copa America title.\n\n\"We\u00b4ve enjoyed him so much,\" Messi said. \"He\u00b4s always given his all and the best of himself and that he will retire in a final is something he simply deserves.\"\n\nArgentina coach Lionel Scaloni held out hope Di Mar\u00eda will reverse his decision.\n\n\"We don't want to start crying right now. We don't want to feel melancholy,\" Scaloni said. \"We have to let him play and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us.\"\n\nSouth American World Cup qualifying resumes in September, with each national team scheduled to play 12 more matches. The 2026 World Cup final will be at MetLife, that July 19.\n\n\"We will never be the ones to close the door,\" Scaloni said. \"He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. {"uri": "2024-07-416898111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:39:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:39:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:36:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/argentina-see-off-canada-to-reach-copa-america-final/article_0b1b6bb2-33cf-5866-aeb7-69dc5bd669a2.html", "title": "Argentina see off Canada to reach Copa America final", "body": "Lionel Messi celebrates scoring Argentina's second goal in a 2-0 victory over Canada\n\nLionel Messi was on target as world champions Argentina turned on the style to beat Canada 2-0 on Tuesday and reach the Copa America final where they will look for a third straight major title.\n\nThe defending Copa champions will face the winners of Wednesday's semi-final between Uruguay and Colombia in what will be a highly anticipated final in Miami on Sunday.\n\nThe 15-times Copa champions produced their best display of the tournament in front of a capacity crowd at the 82,500 MetLife Stadium and as in their 2022 World Cup triumph they look to be peaking at the perfect moment.\n\n\"The truth is that it's crazy what this group has done, what the Argentina national team has been doing,\" Messi told TyC Sports after his first goal of the tournament.\n\n\"It's not easy for us to be in a final again, for us to compete again to be champions. I'm living it like I lived it in the last Copa America, in the last World Cup...These are the last battles and I'm enjoying them to the maximum,\" said the 37-year-old.\n\nCanada, who surprised many by reaching the last four in their first Copa America appearance, can take great credit for their run in the tournament but Messi and company were simply a step too far.\n\n\"I think the tournament caught up with us a little bit,\" said Canada's American coach Marsch, who said he noticed that his players looked tired midway through the first half.\n\n\"Eventually the physicality and fatigue can catch up with you and that was a big part of what happened with us tonight,\" he added.\n\nMarsch's side had progressed by hitting teams with high-energy football straight out of the gate but after an early opening for left-winger Jacob Shaffelburg, who fired wide after cutting in from the flank, the South Americans took control and never gave it up.\n\nAngel Di Maria, the veteran wide-man playing in his final tournament for his country, was seeing plenty of the ball down the right and he offered an early warning of his threat when he picked out Messi with a ball inside which the forward flashed just wife of the post.\n\nBut it was Rodrigo De Paul who was to create the breakthrough in the 22nd minute, picking the ball up on the half-way line, taking a quick glance up and then lofting the ball over the top to Julian Alvarez.\n\nThe Manchester City forward, recalled to the starting line-up ahead of Lautaro Martinez, delivered a deft first touch that took him away from Moises Bombito and gave him just enough room to drive the ball home.\n\n- Classy triangle -\n\nThe classy triangle of Di Maria, Messi and De Paul, was a constant source of danger for Canada's back line and the former threatened a second with a chip from the right which floated over the bar.\n\nThe assuredness of Argentina's build-up play reflects the confidence of coach Lionel Scaloni's team, a well-drilled unit but one that never allows their organisational solidity dominate over their creativity.\n\nTwo minutes before the break, former Real Madrid winger Di Maria provided a slide-rule pass to Messi, who worked himself space for a shot on his right-foot, but he was narrowly wide of Max Crepeau's right-hand post.\n\nCanada's American coach Marsch had plenty of work to do at the interval if he was to find a way of getting his team back on level terms and any strategy went out of the window when the world champions doubled their lead, just six minutes after the restart.\n\nThe excellent De Paul pulled the ball back from the byline to Enzo Fernandez and his side-foot shot was directed home by Messi in front of goal.\n\nFor a moment Canada had hope that Messi may have been offside but the VAR review showed that defender Derek Cornelius had played him onside.\n\nThe two-goal cushion established, Argentina were content to sit back and preserve their energy and invite the Canadians to take them on.\n\nIt was not until the final minutes though that Canada were able to trouble Emiliano Martinez with substitute Tani Oluwaseyi forcing the keeper into action after some sloppy defending.\n\nBut it was a comfortable victory for Scaloni's men and one which leaves them one win away from a record 16th Copa America triumph.\n\nsev/rcw\n\nMore from this section\n\nKickstarter It's something I just live each day. I'm 37 years and only God knows when the end will be.\"\n\nMessi scored his 109th international goal, his first in this year's tournament. It was his 14th in Copa America play, three shy of the record.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or winner spoke outside the locker room at MetLife Stadium, where he announced his retirement after missing a penalty kick in the shootout loss to Chile in the 2016 Copa America final. He reversed his decision seven weeks later and has scored 54 goals in 73 international appearances since, raising his matches for Argentina to 186 as he helped win the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.\n\nTeammate \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda does intend to retire after Sunday's game against Uruguay or Colombia at Miami Gardens, Florida. The 36-year-old Di Mar\u00eda made his international debut in 2008 and has 31 goals in 144 appearances,\n\n\"It's my last battle. There's nothing left to say that I haven't said a lot of times before,\" Di Mar\u00eda explained. \"It's my last game. I have to say thank you to all Argentineans and to this generation that has allowed me to lift so many trophies.\"\n\nDi Mar\u00eda joined with Messi to lead Argentina to it's third World Cup and 15th Copa America title.\n\n\"We've enjoyed him so much,\" Messi said. \"He's always given his all and the best of himself and that he will retire in a final is something he simply deserves.\"\n\nArgentina coach Lionel Scaloni held out hope Di Mar\u00eda will reverse his decision.\n\n\"We don't want to start crying right now. We don't want to feel melancholy,\" Scaloni said. \"We have to let him play and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us.\"\n\nSouth American World Cup qualifying resumes in September, with each national team scheduled to play 12 more matches. The 2026 World Cup final will be at MetLife, that July 19.\n\n\"We will never be the ones to close the door,\" Scaloni said. \"He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great. And if he wants to come with me to somewhere else, I will take him everywhere so he can decide whatever he wants to do.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Copa America coverage: https://apnews.com/hub/copa-america", {"uri": "8218021118", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:58:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:58:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:57:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/football/copa-america-2024-argentina-reaches-final-lionel-scaloni-post-match-quotes-di-maria-messi-retirment-arg-v-can/article68387812.ece", "title": "No bed of roses - Scaloni hails Argentina's grit after making Copa America 2024 final", "body": "Argentina's path to the Copa America final has been no bed of roses, coach Lionel Scaloni said, as he lauded his players for their performance in Tuesday's 2-0 semi-final win over Canada.\n\nCanada, ranked 48th in the world, played high-energy football and looked to turn the match into a physical battle but Argentina's quality shone through in the end.\n\nJulian Alvarez and Lionel Messi scored to secure Argentina's spot in the final of a third straight major tournament after their victories at the 2022 World Cup and Copa America in 2021.\n\n\"It is extremely tough to reach another final. It is tough because we know how hard it is to get there,\" Scaloni told reporters.\n\n\"The bar has been set very high. Everyone thought it was going to be a bed of roses and it wasn't like that at all. Canada proved it today by being a very difficult opponent.\"\n\nALSO READ: Copa America 2024: Messi says he is enjoying \"last battles\" for Argentina\n\nThis edition of Copa America is likely to represent the last chance for many senior squad members to add to their trophy collection with the national team.\n\nAngel di Maria, 36, said last year he would retire from international football after the Copa America, while Messi, 37, and Nicolas Otamendi, 36, are both nearing the end of their careers.\n\n\"You know how I feel about Angel. We don't want to retire him earlier than needed,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"We don't want to feel melancholy. We have to let him play, and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us. But so far, he's here, and he has to be allowed to enjoy this moment.\n\n\"For Leo (Messi), it's similar to Angel. We have to let him be and we will never be the ones to close the door. He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great.\"\n\nIn Sunday's final, Argentina could face either Uruguay, which beat it in a World Cup qualifier in November, or Colombia, which is on a 27-match unbeaten run under coach Nestor Lorenzo.\n\n\"These two potential opponents are top-notch national teams, but it would be reckless to say that I prefer one or the other,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"One of them already beat us. It was a very tough match. We have not played against Colombia with this coach, but we know it could be very difficult as well.\"\n\nLatest on SportstarNo bed of roses - Scaloni hails Argentina's grit after making Copa America It's something I just live each day. I'm 37 years and only God knows when the end will be.\"Messi scored his 109th international goal, his first in this year's tournament. It was his 14th in Copa America play, three shy of the record.The eight-time Ballon d'Or winner spoke outside the locker room at MetLife Stadium, where he announced his retirement after missing a penalty kick in the shootout loss to Chile in the 2016 Copa America final. He reversed his decision seven weeks later and has scored 54 goals in 73 international appearances since, raising his matches for Argentina to 186 as he helped win the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.Teammate \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda does intend to retire after Sunday's game against Uruguay or Colombia at Miami Gardens, Florida. There's nothing left to say that I haven't said a lot of times before,\" Di Mar\u00eda explained. \"It's my last game. I have to say thank you to all Argentineans and to this generation that has allowed me to lift so many trophies.\"Di Mar\u00eda joined with Messi to lead Argentina to it's third World Cup and 15th Copa America title.\"We've enjoyed him so much,\" Messi said. \"He's always given his all and the best of himself and that he will retire in a final is something he simply deserves.\"Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni held out hope Di Mar\u00eda will reverse his decision.\"We don't want to start crying right now. We don't want to feel melancholy,\" Scaloni said. \"We have to let him play and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us.\" South American World Cup qualifying resumes in September, with each national team scheduled to play 12 more matches. {"uri": "8218400838", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "09:30:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T09:30:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:30:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/lionel-messi-inspires-argentina-to-second-consecutive-copa-am-rica-final/article_d527ac56-c9b1-5a42-b942-ad7f589a6a6f.html", "title": "Lionel Messi inspires Argentina to second consecutive Copa Am\u00e9rica final", "body": "(CNN) -- Lionel Messi helped guide Argentina to this year's Copa Am\u00e9rica final after scoring in his nation's 2-0 win against Canada in the semifinals on Tuesday.\n\nThe 37-year-old scored early in the second half to double Argentina's lead after Juli\u00e1n \u00c1lvarez had given La Albiceleste a first-half lead.\n\nIt means Argentina has now reached the Copa Am\u00e9rica final in six of the previous eight tournaments, with this being its second in row - the South American side won the 2021 title.\n\n\"Let's enjoy what we are experiencing as a national team, as a group. It is not easy to be in a final again, to compete again to be champions,\" Messi told TyC Sports after the match, per Reuters.\n\n\"I'm living it as I have been living everything lately: enjoying it very much and being aware.\"\n\nArgentina will face either Uruguay or Colombia in Sunday's final which will be held at the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida.\n\nCanada head coach Jesse Marsch told reporters before the semifinal that he was aware just how difficult it would be to play Argentina, but his side started well against the reigning world champion.\n\nCanada winger Jacob Shaffelburg, though, was made to rue two missed opportunities in the early stages as Argentina striker \u00c1lvarez opened the scoring with a composed touch and finish in the 22nd minute.\n\nThe goal was a sign of the quality that Canada, the world No. 48, was up against.\n\nMessi, possibly playing at his final Copa Am\u00e9rica for Argentina, then started finding his stride and went close twice before the end of the first half.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or winner eventually got his goal shortly into the second half as Enzo Fern\u00e1ndez's shot deflected off the Inter Miami forward, catching Canada goalkeeper Maxime Cr\u00e9peau off guard.\n\nCanada is now the 38th team that Lionel Messi has scored against while playing for his country, per Opta.\n\nDespite not reaching the final, Canada impressed at this year's tournament and showed promising signs for the upcoming World Cup in 2026, which it's co-hosting alongside Mexico and the US.\n\n\"[The tournament] has gone way better than any of us could have scripted,\" Marsch told reporters after the game.\n\n\"There is still a lot of work to do, but we've built a really good foundation and I'm really optimistic about what the future can look like.\"\n\nCanada will now play the loser of the other semifinal in the third-place playoff on Saturday.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. If we were five minutes late, we'd get a fine. There'd be a big problem. Let's see what happens with Argentina. I think they have to be fined,\" Marsch explained.\n\nDespite Argentina abiding by the timings in the second meeting, the 2-0 scoreline remained identical which helped Messi create an impressive piece of history.\n\nVictory on Wednesday means Messi has taken his country to seven major international finals, with five in the Copa America and two in the World Cup.\n\nThe 36-year-old surpasses Brazilian legends Cafu and Roberto Carlos who each reached six finals.\n\nThe Inter Miami star has won two of his six finals so far and will be desperate to add a third to his trophy cabinet as he {"uri": "2024-07-417106482", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:59:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:59:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:05:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.beaumontenterprise.com/sports/article/lionel-messi-says-he-will-keep-on-playing-for-19564377.php", "title": "Lionel Messi says he will keep on playing for Argentina beyond Copa America final", "body": "EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. (AP) -- Lionel Messi plans to keep playing for Argentina beyond Sunday's Copa America final.\n\n\"As I've said before, I intend to continue,\" he said Tuesday night after Argentina's 2-0 win over Canada. \"I intend to keep living day by day without thinking about what will come in the future or whether I'll continue or not. It's something I just live each day. I'm 37 years and only God knows when the end will be.\"\n\nMessi scored his 109th international goal, his first in this year's tournament. It was his 14th in Copa America play, three shy of the record.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or winner spoke outside the locker room at MetLife Stadium, where he announced his retirement after missing a penalty kick in the shootout loss to Chile in the 2016 Copa America final. He reversed his decision seven weeks later and has scored 54 goals in 73 international appearances since, raising his matches for Argentina to 186 as he helped win the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.\n\nTeammate \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda does intend to retire after Sunday's game against Uruguay or Colombia at Miami Gardens, Florida. The 36-year-old Di Mar\u00eda made his international debut in 2008 and has 31 goals in 144 appearances,\n\n\"It's my last battle. There's nothing left to say that I haven't said a lot of times before,\" Di Mar\u00eda explained. \"It's my last game. I have to say thank you to all Argentineans and to this generation that has allowed me to lift so many trophies.\"\n\nDi Mar\u00eda joined with Messi to lead Argentina to it's third World Cup and 15th Copa America title.\n\n\"We've enjoyed him so much,\" Messi said. \"He's always given his all and the best of himself and that he will retire in a final is something he simply deserves.\"\n\nArgentina coach Lionel Scaloni held out hope Di Mar\u00eda will reverse his decision.\n\n\"We don't want to start crying right now. We don't want to feel melancholy,\" Scaloni said. \"We have to let him play and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us.\"\n\nSouth American World Cup qualifying resumes in September, with each national team scheduled to play 12 more matches. The 2026 World Cup final will be at MetLife, that July 19.\n\n\"We will never be the ones to close the door,\" Scaloni said. \"He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great. Uruguay also has 15 titles.\n\nMessi, who was hampered by a groin/thigh injury earlier in the tourney, looked reinvigorated on a hot and humid night playing on a sand-laden, natural-grass field.\n\nAfter Julian Alvarez scored in the 22nd minute, Messi made it 2-0 in the 51st minute when he used his left foot to redirect a shot by Enzo Fernandez. It wasn't a typical Messi goal, but it still counted as his 109th for his country and 14th in his Copa America career.\n\nEarlier, Messi brought the crowd of 80,102 to its feet in the 12th minute when he whipped a shot from the edge of the box a foot outside the right post.\n\nAlvarez, who scored the first goal of the tournament on June 20 in the 2-0 win over the Canadians, did it to them again after Argentina absorbed some early forays into its end by the lone remaining CONCACAF representative.\n\nRodrigo De Paul was near midfield when he sent a through ball forward. Alvarez, who plays for Manchester City, perfectly timed his run and with one touch pushed the ball ahead of the back line. (AP) -- Lionel Messi plans to keep playing for Argentina beyond Sunday's Copa America final.\n\n\"As I've said before, I intend to continue,\" he said Tuesday night after Argentina's 2-0 win over Canada. \"I intend to keep living day by day without thinking about what will come in the future or whether I'll continue or not. It's something I just live each day. I'm 37 years and only God knows when the end will be.\"\n\nMessi scored his 109th international goal, his first in this year's tournament. It was his 14th in Copa America play, three shy of the record.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or winner spoke outside the locker room at MetLife Stadium, where he announced his retirement after missing a penalty kick in the shootout loss to Chile in the 2016 Copa America final. He reversed his decision seven weeks later and has scored 54 goals in 73 international appearances since, raising his matches for Argentina to 186 as he helped win the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.\n\nTeammate \u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda does intend to retire after Sunday's game against Uruguay or Colombia at Miami Gardens, Florida. The 36-year-old Di Mar\u00eda made his international debut in 2008 and has 31 goals in 144 appearances,\n\n\"It's my last battle. There's nothing left to say that I haven't said a lot of times before,\" Di Mar\u00eda explained. \"It's my last game. I have to say thank you to all Argentineans and to this generation that has allowed me to lift so many trophies.\"\n\nDi Mar\u00eda joined with Messi to lead Argentina to it's third World Cup and 15th Copa America title.\n\n\"We've enjoyed him so much,\" Messi said. \"He's always given his all and the best of himself and that he will retire in a final is something he simply deserves.\"\n\nArgentina coach Lionel Scaloni held out hope Di Mar\u00eda will reverse his decision.\n\n\"We don't want to start crying right now. We don't want to feel melancholy,\" Scaloni said. \"We have to let him play and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us.\"\n\nSouth American World Cup qualifying resumes in September, with each national team scheduled to play 12 more matches. The 2026 World Cup final will be at MetLife, that July 19.\n\n\"We will never be the ones to close the door,\" Scaloni said. \"He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great. And if he wants to come with me to somewhere else, I will take him everywhere so he can decide whatever he wants to do.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8218010488", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:47:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:47:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:45:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com/stories/soccer/lionel-messi-back-score-sheet-just-time-argentinas-copa-america-title-defense", "title": "Lionel Messi is back on the score sheet, just in time for Argentina's Copa Am\u00e9rica title defense", "body": "It wasn't anything fancy -- in the 51st minute, Enzo Fern\u00e1ndez found himself alone at the top of the box after a failed clearance by Canada. The Chelsea midfielder controlled the ball with his left foot and struck it with his right, and while the shot may have been going in anyway, Messi got a piece of it as the ball slipped past a diving Maxime Crepeau.\n\nMessi's goal sealed Argentina's 2-0 win over Canada in Tuesday night's semifinal at MetLife Stadium, clinching a spot in Sunday's final in his current hometown of Miami (8 p.m. ET on FOX and the FOX Sports app). La Albiceleste will face the winner of Wednesday's semifinal between Uruguay and Colombia (8 p.m. ET on FS1).\n\nThe Euro 2024 final is also on Sunday (3 p.m. ET on FOX and the FOX Sports app), and Spain will be there, due in part to 16-year-old Lamine Yamal making history by becoming the youngest player to score a goal in the history of the tournament in a 2-1 victory over France. After the match, he tweeted a photo of him and Messi from 2007 that recently went viral.\n\nMessi scored his first career goal at Copa Am\u00e9rica on July 9, 2007; Yamal was born four days later.\n\nMessi's goal against Canada marked his 14th in 38 career Copa Am\u00e9rica appearances. In tournaments that he has scored in, though, this is the longest it has taken him to nab that first goal. For recent comparison's sake, Messi scored seven at the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, including twice in the final.\n\nIt's no secret that the 37-year-old superstar hasn't been 100% healthy. He struggled with a hamstring injury earlier in the year that forced him to miss multiple matches for Inter Miami. And during Copa Am\u00e9rica, he's been hampered by a right groin/adductor injury that kept him on the bench for Argentina's third group stage match -- a 2-0 win over Peru.\n\nHe played the full 90 minutes of Argentina's quarterfinal against Ecuador, but was impressively contained for the most part and had limited touches. That match turned into a penalty shootout and Messi, taking the first kick, uncharacteristically missed from the spot after an attempted Panenka hit the crossbar.\n\nThere were other lost opportunities before that, like in the opening match against Canada and in the second one vs. Chile. Against La Roja, he attempted an olimpico -- or scoring directly from a corner kick, which is something he'd never done -- but it didn't work out.\n\nOf course, he's contributed to goals and created chances for his teammates. And even when Messi isn't manufacturing all the magic, Argentina has proven it can win -- against Canada, Julian Alvarez's smooth goal in the 22nd minute might have been enough.\n\n\"We have Leo, but we know that the entire team is there and if they are not performing well all together, we're going to suffer,\" coach Lionel Scaloni said via an interpreter. \"And we do everything as a team. There's a great level of togetherness and unity. They're very strong together.\"\n\nAnd that's an important exercise for this squad, because one day, it will have to learn how to compete without Messi on a permanent basis.\n\nThough Scaloni will tell you that there's no rush on his end.\n\n\"We have to let him be and we will never be the ones to close the door [on his national team career],\" Scaloni said. \"He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire, but still come and hang around, that would be great.\"\n\nMessi's supporters would love that. The sellout crowd -- many of whom were wearing his No. 10 jersey -- were grateful to witness his 109th international goal. They were there early, setting up tailgates on the stadium grounds more than four hours before kickoff. When the jumbotron showed Messi getting off the team bus upon arrival, those who were already inside MetLife gave him a standing ovation. When Messi took a corner kick in the 35th minute, fans in the northeast corner contorted their bodies in order to get the best angle while holding up their smartphones to snap a once-in-a-lifetime photo of their favorite player. When he missed a quality shot in the 44th minute, the more than 80,000 fans in attendance collectively sighed.\n\nNow, Argentina has the chance to become the first team since Spain (which won the 2008 Euros, 2010 World Cup and 2012 Euros) to win three straight major championships (2021 Copa Am\u00e9rica, 2022 World Cup, and now, maybe, the 2024 Copa Am\u00e9rica).\n\nScaloni said he's not interested in those kinds of statistics because \"the most important thing is to win.\" And while it's been clear this summer that Messi doesn't always have to score for Argentina to do that, everyone {"uri": "8218738262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:56:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:56:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:56:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.nairaland.com/8149881/messi-guides-argentina-another-copa", "title": "Messi Guides Argentina To Another Copa Final (Photos)", "body": "EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- Under a hot, sticky sky, Argentina and Lionel Messi sealed their second consecutive Copa Am\u00e9rica final -- and fourth in past five tournaments -- with a 2-0 win over Canada on Tuesday.\n\nThanks to goals from Manchester City's Juli\u00e1n \u00c0lvarez and Messi, Argentina secured a strong and somewhat painless victory over the Copa's last remaining Concacaf nation. It was also Messi's 109th international goal, passing Ali Daei for second-most men's international goals of all time.\n\nCanada, in quintessential Jesse Marsch fashion, started with a lot of energy as their high press aimed to make Argentina just as uncomfortable as the weather at MetLife stadium. Nashville SC's Jacob Shaffelburg tested Gonzalo Montiel's right side early in the game, but in the end, it came to nothing.\n\nAs the first half developed, that Canadian press and aggression deflated, and Argentina started to take more control as Messi attempted a low, left-footed shot in the 12th minute. Canada was not bowing down, and it looked to capitalize on loose possession, but it still couldn't find the right pass to fully threaten Argentina keeper Emiliano Mart\u00ednez\n\nAnd when you play Argentina, you have to take any chance you get, because if you don't, Lionel Scaloni's side will eventually make you pay.\n\nThey are, after all, FIFA's best-ranked team and World Cup and Copa Am\u00e9rica defending champions for a reason.\n\nAnd in the 22nd minute, La Albiceleste took the lead following a great through ball from Rodrigo De Paul that found \u00c0lvarez. It was \u00c0lvarez's second goal in the tournament and again, just like in the opening game during the group stages, he initiated the scoring against Canada\n\nThe evaporation of Canada's in-your-face approach allowed Argentina to become the complete protagonists. As for Messi's first half? He was relatively quiet in terms of threat, but his movement in the midfield and ability to spread the ball around was present. In the 44th minute, a beautiful play between \u00c1ngel D\u00ed Mar\u00eda, \u00c0lvarez and Messi nearly ended with the Inter Miami CF star scoring a goal, but Messi placed it just wide of Maxime Cr\u00e9peau's net.\n\nBy the end of the first half, Argentina had more than 60% possession and eight attempts. Aside from an effort after a throw-in, which needed Mart\u00ednez to deny Alphonso Davies, the defending Copa Am\u00e9rica champions were in full control.\n\nIn the end, the game was done and dusted after the first goal, and Argentina made it to yet another Copa Am\u00e9rica final. Next up for them is a return to Hard Rock Stadium and their home away from home of Miami. It's something I just live each day. I'm 37 years and only God knows when the end will be.\"\n\nMessi scored his 109th international goal, his first in this year's tournament. It was his 14th in Copa America play, three shy of the record.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or winner spoke outside the changing room at MetLife Stadium, where he announced his retirement after missing a penalty kick in the shootout loss to Chile in the 2016 Copa America final. He reversed his decision seven weeks later and has scored 54 goals in 73 international appearances since, raising his matches for Argentina to 186 as he helped win the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.\n\nTeammate Angel Di Maria does intend to retire after Sunday's game against Uruguay or Colombia at Miami Gardens, Florida. The 36-year-old Di Mar\u00efa made his international debut in 2008 and has 31 goals in 144 appearances,\n\n\"It's my last battle. There's nothing left to say that I haven't said a lot of times before,\" Di Mar\u00efa explained. \"It's my last game. I have to say thank you to all Argentineans and to this generation that has allowed me to lift so many trophies.\"\n\nDi Mar\u00efa joined with Messi to lead Argentina to it's third World Cup and 15th Copa America title.\n\n\"We've enjoyed him so much,\" Messi said. \"He's always given his all and the best of himself and that he will retire in a final is something he simply deserves.\"\n\nArgentina coach Lionel Scaloni held out hope Di Mar\u00efa will reverse his decision.\n\n\"We don't want to start crying right now. We don't want to feel melancholy,\" Scaloni said. \"We have to let him play and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us.\"\n\nSouth American World Cup qualifying resumes in September, with each national team scheduled to play 12 more matches. The 2026 World Cup final will be at MetLife, that July 19.\n\n\"We will never be the ones to close the door,\" Scaloni said. \"He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. However, Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni wants European teams in the competition to prove that the tournament is more difficult than it looks.\n\nArgentina currently holds the top position globally and are on the brink of securing a third trophy from their last three major tournaments. Since taking over as head coach in 2018, Scaloni has rejuvenated the football team, bringing major success back to the country.\n\nHe guided Argentina to their first Copa America title since 1993 in 2021. The following year, he achieved another milestone by leading the team to win the World Cup, a feat that had eluded Argentina since 1986.\n\nSome say he is the best thing that has happened to captain Lionel Messi, after many thought he would go trophyless with his home nation despite such an illustrious career.\n\nOn Sunday, Messi could be lifting his third trophy with Argentina in just three years and critics have responded to this by claiming the competition isn't good enough in Copa America compared to the Euros.\n\nAn angry Scaloni replied: 'I don't think it's more difficult from one competition to another. 'There are some important teams that have advanced to the semi-finals of the Euros, teams that we faced in the World Cup and it went well for us. But that doesn't mean that we could go to the European Championship and win it.'\n\n'Or maybe yes (we could win it). I think the level is very even. 'I would like a European team to one day be invited to a Copa America to see what it is like to play in a Copa America and the opposite, as well.\n\n'But that would be a World Cup, right? So, in the end the difficulty is the same. I don't think there's much difference, really. But these are just opinions.'\n\nIt's unclear yet who Argentina will face in the final as Uruguay v Columbia kicks off at 8pm EST this Wednesday evening. It's something I just live each day. I'm 37 years and only God knows when the end will be.\"\n\nIt was Messi's 109th international goal, his first in this edition of the tournament, which made him the second highest scorer in history surpassing Iran's Ali Daei.\n\nMessi had earlier retired after missing a penalty kick in a shootout defeat to Chile in the 2016 Copa America final but later made a u-turn playing leading roles in Argentina's win in the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.\n\nHowever, Messi's team-mate Angel Di Maria doesn't see himself continuing for the national team beyond Sunday's final.\n\n\"It's my last battle. There's nothing left to say that I haven't said a lot of times before,\" the 36-year-old said, who made his debut in 2008 scoring 31 goals in 144 appearances\n\n\"It's my last game. I have to say thank you to all Argentineans and to this generation that has allowed me to lift so many trophies.\"\n\n\"We've enjoyed him so much.
