It is tough because we know how hard it is to get there,\" Scaloni told reporters.\n\n\"The bar has been set very high. Everyone thought it was going to be a bed of roses and it wasn't like that at all. Canada proved it today by being a very difficult opponent.\"\n\nThis edition of the Copa America is likely to represent the last chance for many senior squad members to add to their trophy collection with the national team.\n\nAngel di Maria, 36, said last year he would retire from international football after the Copa America, while Messi, 37, and Nicolas Otamendi, 36, are both nearing the end of their careers.\n\n\"You know how I feel about Angel. We don't want to retire him earlier than needed,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"We don't want to feel melancholy. We have to let him play, and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us. But so far, he's here, and he has to be allowed to enjoy this moment.\n\n\"For Leo (Messi), it's similar to Angel. We have to let him be and we will never be the ones to close the door. He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great.\"\n\nIn Sunday's final, Argentina could face either Uruguay, who beat them in a World Cup qualifier in November, or This will be a record-extending 30th final appearance for the Argentinian football team.\n\nLionel Messi's team has reached a major final for the third time in a row. The Albiceleste won the 2021 Copa America, defeating Brazil 1-0 in the final. They went on to win the 2022 Qatar World Cup, defeating France 4-2 on penalties after the final was deadlocked 3-3 in extra time.\n\nComing to the encounter against the Canadian side, Argentina were looking comfortable from the start. They created chances and attacked the opponent's goal from the start.\n\nManchester City striker Julian Alvarez scored the first goal for his national side by cutting two defenders in the 22nd minute and was assisted by Rodrigo De Paul.\n\nSkipper Lionel Messi doubled his side's lead when he scored a goal in the 51st minute. {"uri": "2024-07-417257281", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:09:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:09:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:43:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/lionel-messi-drops-massive-retirement-hint-after-leading-argentina-into-the-copa-america-final", "title": "Lionel Messi drops massive retirement hint after leading Argentina into the Copa America final", "body": "Lionel Messi, Argentina's captain, has hinted that he might be contemplating retirement. The 36-year-old Argentine star suggested that he is fighting his \"last battles\" for his national team. This statement has left fans wondering if they are witnessing the final chapter of Messi's illustrious international career.\n\nIn the recent Copa America semi-final, Messi scored Argentina's second goal against Canada, helping his team secure a spot in the final. The goal came as Messi deflected Enzo Fernandez's shot into the net, marking his first goal of the 2024 Copa America. Before this, Messi had not scored in the tournament but provided an assist in a group-stage game against Canada. Argentina has been dominant against Canada, winning 2-0 in both encounters.\n\nLionel Messi reflects on his Argentina career\n\nAfter the semi-final victory, Messi spoke to D Sports Radio, expressing his awareness that his career is nearing its end. \"Yes, I am aware that these are the last battles... I am enjoying them to the fullest,\" he said. Messi emphasized the importance of savoring every moment on the field, especially as reaching a final is never an easy feat. His words reflect a deep appreciation for the game and the experiences it has brought him over the years.\n\nMessi's reflective comments are a testament to his long and successful career. He has achieved almost everything there is to achieve in football, from multiple Ballon d'Or awards to club championships with Barcelona and a World Cup win with Argentina. His journey has been filled with ups and downs, but his passion for the sport has always shone through.\n\nArgentina's journey to the final has been impressive, showcasing the team's skill and determination. Messi's leadership and contributions on the field have been crucial to their success. As they prepare for the final, Argentina will closely watch the outcome of the other semi-final between Uruguay and Colombia. The winner of that match will face Argentina in the final on Sunday night.\n\nThe uncertain future\n\nDespite hinting at retirement, Messi has not entirely ruled out the possibility of continuing his international career. There is still a chance that fans might see him play in the 2026 World Cup, which will be held in North America. For now, though, Messi remains focused on the immediate task at hand - helping Argentina win the Copa America.\n\nThe upcoming final could potentially be Messi's last game for Argentina, making it a highly anticipated event for football fans around the world. Messi's impact on the sport and his contributions to Argentina's national team have been immense. His journey has been filled with remarkable achievements, memorable moments, and countless accolades.\n\nAs the final approaches, Messi's fans are left with mixed emotions. On one hand, there is excitement and hope that Argentina will lift the trophy. On the other hand, there is a sense of nostalgia and sadness, knowing that Messi's time on the international stage might be drawing to a close.\n\nIn addition to his on-field achievements, Messi's influence extends beyond football. He is a role model for many young athletes, admired for his dedication, humility, and sportsmanship. His potential retirement marks the end of an era not just for Argentina but for football as a whole.\n\nMessi's recent comments have sparked speculation about his retirement. As Argentina prepares for the Copa America final, the focus is on the present moment and the opportunity to win another title. Whether this final marks the end of Messi's international career or just another milestone in his legendary journey, fans will be eagerly watching, cherishing every moment of Messi's brilliance on the field. The upcoming match promises to be a thrilling and emotional event, as Argentina aims for glory with their iconic captain leading the way.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8218127432", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "06:27:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T06:27:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T06:26:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/top-stories/enjoing-my-last-battles-for-argentina-to-the-maximum-lionel-messi/articleshow/111625467.cms", "title": "'Enjoing my last battles for Argentina to the maximum' - Lionel Messi | Football News - Times of India", "body": "Lionel Messi expressed his delight in participating in his \"last battles\" for Argentina following their 2-0 victory against Canada on Tuesday, which secured their spot in the Copa America final.\n\n\"I'm living it like I lived it in the last Copa America, in the last World Cup....these are the last battles and I'm enjoying them to the maximum,\" Messi said talking to TyC Sports.\n\nThe 37-year-old legend scored the second goal for Argentina in their semifinal victory. The world champions will meet either Uruguay or Colombia in the final.\n\nMessi's performance was a marked improvement from the quarterfinal against Ecuador, where he appeared to be below his usual standards. In the semis, he showcased his exceptional skills, linking up effectively with teammates Angel Di Maria and Julian Alvarez, who also found the back of the net.\n\nMessi, who currently plas club football for Inter Miami in the Major League Soccer, has not yet revealed his plans regarding his participation with the Argentine national team in the upcoming 2026 World Cup.\n\nIn response to Messi's remark about his \"last battles,\" the head coach of Argentina, Lionel Scaloni, urged for composure and restraint in speculation.\n\n\"We have to leave him alone; he knows that we will not be the ones to close the door on him. He can stay with us as long as he wants, even when he retires...Let him decide what he wants,\" he said.\n\nMessi has the opportunity to secure a third consecutive major trophy with Argentina's national team, building on their recent successes in the 2022 World Cup and the 2021 Copa America.\n\nThe Argentine superstar, who has won the prestigious Ballon d'Or award eight times, acknowledged the contributions of his long-time colleagues Di Maria and Nicolas Otamendi.\n\nMessi emphasized that the team's recent triumphs serve as a testament to their resilience and perseverance through the challenging and trophy-less periods they had endured in the past.\n\n\"The truth is that it's crazy what this group has done, what the Argentina national team has been doing, because after all this, it gives value to all (the tournaments) I and the old generation have played in,\" Messi said on TyC Sports.\n\n\"It's not easy for us to be in a final again, for us to compete again to be champions,\" he added after the victory at MetLife Stadium.\n\nMessi acknowledged that the journey to the championship match had been challenging.\n\n\"It's a difficult Copa, evenly matched, with very bad pitches, with high temperatures, very tough teams, and for us to be in a final again is something to enjoy,\" he said.\n\nThe TOI Sports Desk excels in a myriad of roles that capture the essence of live sporting events and deliver compelling content to readers worldwide. From running live blogs for India and non-India cricket matches to global spectacles featuring Indian talents, like the Chess World Cup final featuring Praggnanandhaa and the Badminton World Championships semifinal featuring HS Prannoy, our live coverage extends to all mega sporting events. We extensively cover events like the Olympics, Asian Games, Cricket World Cups, FIFA World Cups, and more. The desk is also adept at writing comprehensive match reports and insightful post-match commentary, complemented by stats-based articles that provide an in-depth analysis of player performances and team dynamics. that Messi himself has spent hours watching YouTube compilations and making detailed notes about a journeyman English second-tier striker from the 2000s.\n\nBack in 2007, David Nugent scored on his sole England appearance by tracking a Jermain Defoe shot to the goalline and belting it into the net.\n\nThe celebration that followed, in a huddle with a visibly peeved Defoe, exhibited the kind of delighted absence of self-awareness that would've made Nugent a government minister in a different universe.\n\nAnd, 17 years later on a boiling night in New Jersey, Messi finally got the chance to emulate his closet hero.\n\nArgentina were leading a plucky Canadian side by a single goal when Enzo Fernandez took advantage of some slack defending to fire a shot towards goal.\n\nShifting his body like a man trying to get to sleep on a humid summer's night, the 37-year-old got a foot on the ball to deflect it home and give his country an unassailable 2-0 lead.\n\nThe kinder judges among us will claim that Messi saw Enzo's shot was travelling towards the net at the speed of an asthmatic ant which the Canada goalkeeper could've stopped it in his sleep, meaning his intervention was both necessary and correct.\n\nBut you and I know better; Messi had yet to score in this Copa America and channelled the energy of his unexpected mentor to snatch a goal from his team-mate.\n\nREAD NEXT: 7 world-class players Lionel Messi has outscored on the international stage since turning 30\n\nTRY A QUIZ: Can you name every trophy that Lionel Messi has won in his career?\n\n\"What this team has done, what the Argentina national team has done, because after this everyone gives more importance to all the finals that me and the 'older guys' have played,\" Messi said after the match.\n\n\"Me, Fide [Angel Di Mar\u00eda], Ota [Nicolas Otamendi], and that Argentina can play another final is amazing.\n\n\"To be honest it has been a difficult tournament, the level has been as equal as ever, very bad surfaces, high temperatures that make it hard to play, very tough rivals.\n\n\"So the fact we made it and we are here again playing a final is something to enjoy and highlight.\"\n\nDuring his post-match interview, Messi spoke about savouring each moment in the iconic Albiceleste jersey, acknowledging that his time on the pitch won't last forever.\n\n\"I am aware that these are the last few battles, that is why I am enjoying it very much,\" said Messi. \"Let's enjoy everything that we are living and enjoying as a national team. It is not easy to get to another final.\n\n\"We have to take advantage because it's not something easy These are some of my last battles and I have to enjoy.\"\n\nExpanding into further detail, Messi said, \"It's crazy what this group has been doing, what the Argentine National Team has been doing, because a lot of importance is being given to the finals that I and all of the old team played in.\n\n\"It's amazing that we're in a new final. It wasn't an easy cup: very tough teams, very bad pitches, the heat makes it very hard. It's worth enjoying being in a new final.\"\n\nManager Lionel Scaloni expressed excitement over reaching this point of the competition, before warning of the difficulties that lie ahead for Argentina.\n\n\"It's something to be proud of and grateful to the players for,\" Scaloni said. \"Yesterday, a colleague asked me if we normalize this, but the question was good and I wasn't clear.\n\n\"It's super difficult to be in a final, especially coming in the way we did with previous success and triumph. It's something I just live each day. I'm 37 years and only God knows when the end will be.\"\n\nMessi scored his 109th international goal, his first in this year's tournament. It was his 14th in Copa America play, three shy of the record.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or winner spoke outside the locker room at MetLife Stadium, where he announced his retirement after missing a penalty kick in the shootout loss to Chile in the 2016 Copa America final. He reversed his decision seven weeks later and has scored 54 goals in 73 international appearances since, raising his matches for Argentina to 186 as he helped win the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.\n\nTeammate Angel Di Maria does intend to retire after Sunday's game against Uruguay or Colombia at Miami Gardens, Florida. The 36-year-old Di Maria made his international debut in 2008 and has 31 goals in 144 appearances.\n\n\"It's my last battle. There's nothing left to say that I haven't said a lot of times before,\" Di Maria explained. \"It's my last game. I have to say thank you to all Argentineans and to this generation that has allowed me to lift so many trophies.\"\n\nDi Maria joined with Messi to lead Argentina to it's third World Cup and 15th Copa America title.\n\n\"We've enjoyed him so much,\" Messi said. \"He's always given his all and the best of himself and that he will retire in a final is something he simply deserves.\"\n\nArgentina coach Lionel Scaloni held out hope Di Maria will reverse his decision.\n\n\"We don't want to start crying right now. We don't want to feel melancholy,\" Scaloni said. \"We have to let him play and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us.\"\n\nSouth American World Cup qualifying resumes in September, with each national team scheduled to play 12 more matches. {"uri": "8219057225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:20:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:20:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:20:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://worldsoccertalk.com/news/who-holds-the-record-for-the-most-international-goals-of-all-time/", "title": "Who holds the record for the most international goals of all time?", "body": "Who holds the record for the most international goals of all time?\n\nNumerous soccer greats have made permanent imprints on the sport's annals. Of all the soccer records, the record for most international goals scored by a player is among the most sought-after. Not only does this accomplishment demonstrate extraordinary skill, but it also demonstrates great consistency and durability. Currently, the record is held by Cristiano Ronaldo, the Portuguese forward famous for his incredible commitment to the sport and his ability to score goals.\n\nBut there has been a shift in the rankings after three years, however, and Ronaldo is under more pressure to maintain his record. This is especially true because Lionel Messi, the Argentine legend, continues to make history.\n\nIn Argentina's 2-0 victory over Canada in the Copa America semifinal, Messi's goal not only propelled his team to the final but also marked a significant personal achievement. By scoring his 109th international goal, Messi surpassed Iran's Ali Daei to become the second-highest international goalscorer in history. He is now only behind his arch-rival, who has 130 goals.\n\nMessi's historic goal came at the MetLife Stadium in New Jersey. During the match, Canada struggled to clear a shot from Enzo Fernandez, and Messi capitalized by redirecting the ball into the net. Initially contested by the Canadian players for a potential offside, the VAR review confirmed that Messi was onside, thanks to Canada's Cornelius, and the goal stood. This goal was Messi's first in the 2024 Copa America and his 14th in the tournament overall.\n\nThe 37-year-old's leadership on the pitch has been crucial for Argentina, especially after missing the previous match against Ecuador. His return to action against Canada not only lifted the team's performance but also added to his illustrious career milestones.\n\nTo add to his feat, his international career has been nothing short of extraordinary. Since reversing his retirement decision in 2016, Messi has scored 54 goals in 73 international appearances, helping Argentina win both the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup. His ability to consistently perform at the highest level, even at 37, is a testament to his dedication and talent.\n\nArgentina will face either Uruguay or Colombia in the Copa America final. Messi's focus remains on leading his team to another title, further cementing Argentina's status as a powerhouse in international soccer. After the Copa America, the superstar will return to MLS action with Inter Miami, continuing his storied career.\n\nAs Messi continues to break records, the soccer world watches closely. The rivalry between Messi and Ronaldo, two of the greatest players in history, remains a captivating storyline. The 39-year-old, who recently played in Euro 2024, will be looking to add to his goal tally with Portugal when the next tournament comes around; as he prepares for the new Saudi Pro League season with Al-Nassr.\n\nWhile Messi and Ronaldo have set incredibly high standards, the next generation of players is already emerging. Players like Kylian Mbappe of France, Vinicius of Brazil, and Erling Haaland of Norway have the potential to challenge these records in the future. However, surpassing the Portuguese's record will require exceptional talent, consistency, and longevity.", "source": {"uri": "worldsoccertalk.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "World Soccer Talk"}, {"uri": "2024-07-417408747", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:17:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:17:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:16:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.sunherald.com/sports/article289913409.html", "title": "Lionel Messi, Argentina shut out Canada to reach Copa America finale", "body": "July 10 (UPI) --Lionel Messi and Julian Alvarez each scored to lead top-ranked Argentina to a 2-0 shutout of No. 48 Canada, clinching a spot in the Copa America finale for the defending tournament champions.\n\nAlvarez found the net in the 22nd minute Tuesday at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. Messi added insurance with another score in the 51st minute. Midfielders Enzo Fernandez and Rodrigo De Paul assisted the forwards.\n\nArgentina will face No. 14 Uruguay or No. 12 Colombia in the Copa America finale at 8 p.m. EDT Sunday at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\n\"It's madness what this team has done, what the Argentinian national team has been doing,\" Messi said in his on-field interview. \"I think that each time we make a final, there's more importance to the finals I have left to play.\"\n\nCanada failed to capitalize on several early chances. Messi nearly scored the opening goal in the 12th minute, but that shot sailed just wide of the right post.\n\nThe Argentines finally broke through midway through the first half. De Paul started the sequence, receiving a pass at midfield. He dribbled into Canada territory and sent a long ball toward the box. Alvarez knocked the pass down with a velvety-soft touch, outpaced the Canada defense and finished the play with a right-footed shot between the legs of goalie Maxime Crepeau for a 1-0 lead.\n\nVeteran winger Angel Di Maria nearly doubled the Argentine lead in the 34th minute, but that attempt flew over the crossbar. Canada's defense also held up, denying more chances in the first half, including several from Messi.\n\nMessi then doubled the lead about five minutes into the second act.\n\nThe star striker dribbled deep in the right corner before passing off to De Paul inside the box. Messi then ran toward the goal, but De Paul's pass back was intercepted by Ismael Kone. The Canada midfielder attempted to clear the ball, but instead sent it directly to Fernandez. Fernandez sent the ball back toward the goal, where Messi redirected a shot off Crepeau and into the net.\n\nCrepeau and Argentine keeper Emiliano Martinez continued to deny attempts down the stretch, helping the result stand. Canada also lost star defender Alphonso Davies to an ankle injury. He left the game in the 71st minute.\n\nUruguay will take on Colombia in the other Copa America semifinal at 8 p.m. Wednesday at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte. The matchup will air on FS1. {"uri": "2024-07-416861080", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "02:32:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T02:32:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T02:05:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240710-argentina-see-off-canada-to-reach-copa-america-final", "title": "Argentina see off Canada to reach Copa America final", "body": "East Rutherford (United States) (AFP) - Lionel Messi was on target as world champions Argentina turned on the style to beat Canada 2-0 on Tuesday and reach the Copa America final where they will look for a third straight major title.\n\nThe defending Copa champions will face the winners of Wednesday's semi-final between Uruguay and Colombia in what will be a highly anticipated final in Miami on Sunday.\n\nThe 15-times Copa champions produced their best display of the tournament in front of a capacity crowd at the 82,500 MetLife Stadium and as in their 2022 World Cup triumph they look to be peaking at the perfect moment.\n\nCanada, who surprised many by reaching the last four in their first Copa America appearance, can take great credit for their run in the tournament but Messi and company were simply a step too far.\n\nJesse Marsch's side had progressed by hitting teams with high-energy football straight out of the gate but after an early opening for left-winger Jacob Shaffelburg, who fired wide after cutting in from the flank, the South Americans took control and never gave it up.\n\nAngel Di Maria, the veteran wide-man playing in his final tournament for his country, was seeing plenty of the ball down the right and he offered an early warning of his threat when he picked out Messi with a ball inside which the forward flashed just wife of the post.\n\nBut it was Rodrigo De Paul who was to create the breakthrough in the 22nd minute, picking the ball up on the half-way line, taking a quick glance up and then lofting the ball over the top to Julian Alvarez.\n\nThe Manchester City forward, recalled to the starting line-up ahead of Lautaro Martinez, delivered a deft first touch that took him away from Moises Bombito and gave him just enough room to drive the ball home.\n\nClassy triangle\n\nThe classy triangle of Di Maria, Messi and De Paul, was a constant source of danger for Canada's back line and the former threatened a second with a chip from the right which floated over the bar.\n\nThe assuredness of Argentina's build-up play reflects the confidence of coach Lionel Scaloni's team, a well-drilled unit but one that never allows their organisational solidity dominate over their creativity.\n\nTwo minutes before the break, former Real Madrid winger Di Maria provided a slide-rule pass to Messi, who worked himself space for a shot on his right-foot, but he was narrowly wide of Max Crepeau's right-hand post.\n\nCanada's American coach Marsch had plenty of work to do at the interval if he was to find a way of getting his team back on level terms and any strategy went out of the window when the world champions doubled their lead, just six minutes after the restart.\n\nThe excellent De Paul pulled the ball back from the byline to Enzo Fernandez and his side-foot shot was directed home by Messi in front of goal.\n\nFor a moment Canada had hope that Messi may have been offside but the VAR review showed that defender Derek Cornelius had played him onside.\n\nThe two-goal cushion established, Argentina were content to sit back and preserve their energy and invite the Canadians to take them on.\n\nIt was not until the final minutes though that Canada were able to trouble Emiliano Martinez with substitute Tani Oluwaseyi forcing the keeper into action after some sloppy defending.\n\nBut it was a comfortable victory for Scaloni's men and one which leaves them one win away from a record 16th Copa America triumph.", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "France 24"}, We'll see later if we convince him or not convince him, but for now we let him play.\n\n\"It's the same case for Messi. We leave them calm from our part, we won't be the ones to close the door on them. He can be with us as long as he wants, and even after he retires he can join me if I'm still coach. And if not I'll take him where I go. He would be a great help.\"\n\nMessi has offered little indication as to when he might retire, but did say after the game: \"We enjoy what we are living as a squad, as a group. It is not easy that we are in a final again and we are about to compete again with the possibility of being champions.\n\n\"A lot of importance is given to the previous finals that me and the 'old guard' have played. These are the last battles we will have with Di Maria and [Nicolas] Otamendi. Surely this is my last Copa.\"\n\nArgentina are the defending Copa champions and backed up their continental success by winning the World Cup in Qatar in 2022.\n\nIt's a remarkable run of success that even the understated Scaloni says should be recognised.\n\n\"It's something to be proud of and grateful to the players for,\" Scaloni said. \"Yesterday, a [media] colleague asked me if we normalise this, but the question was good and I wasn't clear.\n\n\"It's super difficult to be in a final, especially coming in the way we did with previous success and triumph. It's twice as hard.\n\n\"The ones on the inside know how difficult it is to reach this point. {"uri": "8217930878", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "03:24:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T03:24:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T03:23:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.batimes.com.ar/news/sports/argentina-see-off-canada-to-reach-copa-america-final.phtml", "title": "Argentina see off Canada to reach Copa Am\u00e9rica final", "body": "Lionel Messi was on target as world champions Argentina turned on the style to beat Canada 2-0 on Tuesday and reach the Copa Am\u00e9rica final where they will look for a third straight major title.\n\nThe defending champions will face the winners of Wednesday's semi-final between Uruguay and Colombia in what will be a highly anticipated final in Miami on Sunday.\n\nThe 15-times Copa Am\u00e9rica champions produced their best display of the tournament in front of a capacity crowd at the 82,500 MetLife Stadium and as in their 2022 World Cup triumph they look to be peaking at the perfect moment.\n\n\"The truth is that it's crazy what this group has done, what the Argentina national team has been doing,\" Messi told TyC Sports after his first goal of the tournament.\n\n\"It's not easy for us to be in a final again, for us to compete again to be champions. I'm living it like I lived it in the last Copa Am\u00e9rica, in the last World Cup... these are the last battles and I'm enjoying them to the maximum,\" said the 37-year-old.\n\nCanada, who surprised many by reaching the last four in their first Copa America appearance, can take great credit for their run in the tournament but Messi and company were simply a step too far.\n\n\"I think the tournament caught up with us a little bit,\" said Canada's US coach Marsch, who said he noticed that his players looked tired midway through the first half.\n\n\"Eventually the physicality and fatigue can catch up with you and that was a big part of what happened with us tonight,\" he added.\n\nMarsch's side had progressed by hitting teams with high-energy football straight out of the gate but after an early opening for left-winger Jacob Shaffelburg, who fired wide after cutting in from the flank, the Albiceleste took control and never gave it up.\n\n\u00c1ngel Di Mar\u00eda, the veteran wide-man playing in his final tournament for his country, was seeing plenty of the ball down the right and he offered an early warning of his threat when he picked out Messi with a ball inside which the forward flashed just wife of the post.\n\nBut it was Rodrigo De Paul who was to create the breakthrough in the 22nd minute, picking the ball up on the half-way line, taking a quick glance up and then lofting the ball over the top to Juli\u00e1n \u00c1lvarez.\n\nThe Manchester City forward, recalled to the starting line-up ahead of Lautaro Mart\u00ednez, delivered a deft first touch that took him away from Moises Bombito and gave him just enough room to drive the ball home.\n\nThe classy triangle of Di Mar\u00eda, Messi and De Paul, was a constant source of danger for Canada's back line and the former threatened a second with a chip from the right which floated over the bar.\n\nThe assuredness of Argentina's build-up play reflects the confidence of coach Lionel Scaloni's team, a well-drilled unit but one that never allows their organisational solidity dominate over their creativity.\n\nTwo minutes before the break, former Real Madrid winger Di Mar\u00eda provided a slide-rule pass to Messi, who worked himself space for a shot on his right-foot, but he was narrowly wide of Max Crepeau's right-hand post.\n\nCanada's US coach Marsch had plenty of work to do at the interval if he was to find a way of getting his team back on level terms and any strategy went out of the window when the world champions doubled their lead, just six minutes after the restart.\n\nThe excellent De Paul pulled the ball back from the byline to Enzo Fern\u00e1ndez and his side-foot shot was directed home by Messi in front of goal.\n\nFor a moment Canada had hope that Messi may have been offside but the VAR review showed that defender Derek Cornelius had played him onside.\n\nThe two-goal cushion established, Argentina were content to sit back and preserve their energy and invite the Canadians to take them on.\n\nIt was not until the final minutes though that Canada were able to trouble Emiliano Mart\u00ednez with substitute Tani Oluwaseyi forcing the keeper into action after some sloppy defending.\n\nBut it was a comfortable victory for Scaloni's men and one which leaves them one win away from a record 16th Copa Am\u00e9rica triumph.", "source": {"uri": "batimes.com.ar", {"uri": "8218220864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:34:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:34:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:34:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2024/0710/1459114-scaloni-hails-old-guard-as-argentina-reach-copa-final/", "title": "Scaloni hails old guard as Argentina reach Copa final", "body": "Argentina's path to the Copa America final has been no bed of roses, coach Lionel Scaloni said, as he lauded his players for their performance in Tuesday night's 2-0 semi-final win over Canada in New Jersey.\n\nCanada, ranked 48th in the world, played high-energy football and looked to turn the match into a physical battle but Argentina's quality shone through in the end.\n\nJulian Alvarez and Lionel Messi scored to secure Argentina's spot in the final of a third straight major tournament after their victories at the 2022 World Cup and Copa America in 2021.\n\n\"It is extremely tough to reach another final. It is tough because we know how hard it is to get there,\" Scaloni said afterwards..\n\n\"The bar has been set very high. Everyone thought it was going to be a bed of roses and it wasn't like that at all. Canada proved it today by being a very difficult opponent.\"\n\nThis edition of the Copa America is likely to represent the last chance for many senior squad members to add to their trophy collection with the national team.\n\nAngel di Maria, 36, said last year he would retire from international football after the tournament, while Messi, 37, and Nicolas Otamendi, 36, are both nearing the end of their careers.\n\n\"You know how I feel about Angel. We don't want to retire him earlier than needed,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"We don't want to feel melancholy. We have to let him play, and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us. But so far, he's here, and he has to be allowed to enjoy this moment.\n\n\"For Leo (Messi), it's similar to Angel. We have to let him be and we will never be the ones to close the door. He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great.\"\n\nMessi described Argentina's success as \"insane\".\n\n\"For those who remain from the old guard, it's beyond impressive that the national team is in another final,\" he said.\n\nHe admitted the tournament in the USA had been \"very difficult\" with \"bad surfaces, excessive heat\".\n\nIn Sunday's final, Argentina could face either Uruguay, who beat them in a World Cup qualifier in November, or Colombia, who are on a 27-match unbeaten run under coach Nestor Lorenzo.\n\n\"These two potential opponents are top-notch national teams, but it would be reckless to say that I prefer one or the other,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"One of them already beat us. It was a very tough match. We have not played against Colombia with this coach, but we know it could be very difficult as well.\"", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTE.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": first goal for Argentina came in the 22nd minute, courtesy of Julian Alvarez.\n\nRodrigo de Paul executed a precise long pass from near the midfield, finding the Manchester City forward, who made a perfectly timed run to score his second goal of the competition from close range.\n\nLa Albiceleste doubled their lead in the 51st minute when Messi broke his scoring drought at the Copa America, Goal reported,\n\nFollowing a set piece, the ball eventually reached Enzo Fernandez, who directed it towards the goal.\n\nThe Inter Miami captain got a slight touch on the ball just before it crossed the to maintain their initial momentum.\n\nMessi and his teammates will now aim for consecutive Copa America titles on Sunday, facing the winner of the Uruguay-Colombia semifinal at Hard Rock Stadium, per {"uri": "8218842323", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "14:00:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T14:00:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T14:00:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10614350/argentina-wins-copa-america-semifinal-canada/", "title": "Argentina earns 2-0 win over gutsy Canada in Copa America semifinal  | Globalnews.ca", "body": "Goals by Lionel Messi and Julian Alvarez lifted top-ranked Argentina past Canada as the star-studded South American side showed its pedigree in a 2-0 win in the Copa America semifinal on Tuesday.\n\nDespite the loss, the 48th-ranked Canadians did not disappoint before a lively crowd of 80,102 on a hot, humid night at MetLife Stadium, home of the NFL's New York Giants and Jets, as well as the venue for the 2026 FIFA World Cup final.\n\nThe loud crowd was largely clad in Argentina blue although there were pockets of red. They saw a gutsy performance from Canada, albeit one lacking in clinical finishing, and pure class from Argentina, whose passing and buildup were straight out of a video game at times.\n\nThe Canadians also fell 2-0 to Argentina when they met in the June 20th tournament opener in Atlanta. Argentina thumped Canada 5-0 in their only other meeting, in May 2010 in Buenos Aires in the Argentines' final warm-up before the FIFA World Cup in South Africa.\n\nMessi and the Argentines will play either No. 12 Colombia or No. 14 Uruguay, who meet Wednesday in Charlotte, N.C., in Sunday's championship game at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\n\"It's insane what this team has done, what the Argentina national team is doing,\" Messi said. \"For those who remain from the old guard, it's beyond impressive that the national team is in another final.\"\n\nCanada heads to Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte for Saturday's third-place game.\n\n\"If we want to be a nation that gains ranking spots and be ready for '26, we got to dig deeper than that tonight even though we give a good effort,\" said Canadian goalkeeper Maxime Crepeau. \"Even though they are the world champions, everybody on the field feels like we could have done better.\n\n\" ... We need to regroup and go for third place.\"\n\nArgentina showed its quality, content to stroke the ball around and then change gears in an instant when it saw an opening in Canada's defence.\n\nAnd despite a positive start, Canada fell behind in the 22nd minute on Argentina's first shot on target. The Canadian defence was carved open by a long pass from Rodrigo De Paul that Alvarez controlled with a fine first touch before outmuscling Moise Bombito and slipping a shot through Crepeau's legs.\n\nCoach Jesse Marsch and the Canadian bench were irate, believing a foul by Argentina's Nicol\u00e1s Tagliafico -- who steamrollered Richie Laryea as he tried to corral Crepeau's goal kick, allowing the South Americans to win possession -- had been missed before the goal. Eight touches later the ball was in the Canada net.\n\nBut Chilean referee Piero Maza was letting the teams play, much to Marsch's displeasure. The Canada coach eventually received a caution in the 77th minute for voicing his displeasure with the officiating.\n\nMessi made it 2-0 in the 51st minute with a slight redirect of an Enzo Fernandez shot through traffic after Canada failed to clear the ball. Canada had eight defenders in front of Crepeau in its penalty box but could not snuff out the threat.\n\nThe goal survived a video review check for offside with Messi getting the green light for his first goal of the tournament and his 14th in career Copa America play.\n\nCanada captain Alphonso Davies had to leave in the 71st minute after being injured in a hard challenge by Gonzalo Montiel that went unpunished.\n\nThere was some bad blood late in the game, with Argentina upset at Canadian midfielder Ismael Kone petulantly kicking the ball into one of their fallen players.\n\nMetLife Stadium's temporary grass surface appeared heavy, with water splashing and sand popping up during dribbles.\n\n\"It's has been a very difficult Copa America, very competitive, bad surfaces, excessive heat,\" Messi said.\n\nThe Canadian men were looking to reach their first tournament final since the 2000 Gold Cup when they upset Colombia to win the CONCACAF crown.\n\nCanada, the last survivor of the six CONCACAF guest teams, is making its Copa debut. The Canadian men beat No. 99 Trinidad and Tobago 2-1 in a March playoff to make the 16-country field -- as the 11th-ranked team at the tournament.\n\nIt has been an eventful competition for the Canadian side under Marsch, the 50-year-old American who has infused his new team with youth and confidence as well as a new skipper in Davies.\n\n\"The tournament caught up with us a little bit,\" said Marsch after the semifinal setback. \"There's been heat, there's been travel, there's been a lot of challenges. ... We're still at the beginnings of our process, right?\n\n\"Argentina's maybe had eight years together, seven years together with this team, and so we need to develop more players that can contribute so that we can also rotate in tournament play, because eventually the physicality and the fatigue can catch up with you.\"\n\nCrepeau has established himself as Canada's No. 1 goalkeeper. Bombito and Derek Cornelius have become the heart of the defence while speedy winger Jacob Shaffelburg has had a breakout tournament.\n\nThere have been challenges.\n\nBombito was the victim of online racial abuse after a hard tackle on Messi in the tournament opener. And winger Tajon Buchanan broke his leg in training.\n\nMarsch made just one change to the starting 11 that beat Venezuela with Kone who scored the decisive penalty in the shootout after coming in on off the bench, slotting in for Jonathan Osorio.\n\nCanada looked to restrict the Argentines with its press from the get-go, coming forward with two early counterattacks that saw Shaffelburg fire shots off-target.\n\nMessi shot just wide in the 11th minute on an Argentine counterattack. And the ever-dangerous Argentina captain just missed again with a low shot late in the first half, followed by an attempted chip over Crepeau in stoppage time.\n\nArgentina 'keeper Emiliano Mart\u00ednez, sporting an Argentina flag dyed into the side of his hair, was called into action in the dying seconds of the half after Jonathan David got to an Alistair Johnston long throw-in, poking the ball toward goal from close range.\n\nFor the second game in a row, Argentina kept Canada waiting to start the second half. After Canada went down 2-0, Crepeau was called into action again to stop Alvarez.\n\nAli Ahmed, Liam Millar, Tani Oluwaseyi, Mathieu Choiniere and Osorio came on for Canada in the second half. The subs helped spark the offence with Canada threatening the South Americans as the clock wound down.\n\nOluwaseyi had two good chances in the dying minutes, with an acrobatic Martinez managing to get his body in front of the first shot in the 89th minute. The Canadian sub then saw his header just go wide.\n\nArgentina came into the semifinal having lost just once in 18 games (16-1-1) since defeating France via penalty shootout in the World Cup final in December 2022. The one loss during that run was a 2-0 defeat at the hands of Uruguay in World Cup qualifying in November. And the draw turned into the penalty shootout win over No. 30 Ecuador last time out.\n\nThat didn't deter Canadian rapper Drake from placing a $300,000 bet on Canada to win, a wager returning $2.88 million if successful. Drake posted the betting slip online, as he often does with his wagers.\n\nAfter losing to Argentina in the tournament opener, Canada beat No. 31 Peru 1-0 and tied No. 40 Chile 0-0 to finish second in Group A behind the Argentines. The Canadians then beat No. 54 Venezuela in a penalty shootout in the quarterfinal.\n\nArgentina is seeking its third major crown after the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup. The Argentines are tied with Uruguay for most Copa America titles with 15.\n\nWhen asked about Davies leaving the game after hurting his right leg in a challenge with Montiel, Marsch said: \"He's getting an X-ray, so we're hopeful he's OK, but we're not sure.\"", "source": {"uri": "globalnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "Global News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Under coach Lionel Scaloni, Argentina aims for their second consecutive Copa Am\u00e9rica title.\n\nThey will face the winner of the Uruguay vs. Colombia match in the final next Sunday at 21:00 (Bras\u00edlia time) at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami, Florida.\n\nArgentina will know their final opponent by Wednesday night. Canada's unexpected journey to the semifinals ended.\n\nHowever, they will play for third place on Saturday at 21:00 against the loser of the Uruguay vs. Colombia match at Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina.\n\nArgentina opened the scoring in the 22nd minute. Rodrigo De Paul saw Juli\u00e1n \u00c1lvarez in space, delivering a through ball.\n\n\u00c1lvarez controlled it, entered the box, and finished between Cr\u00e9peau's legs at MetLife Stadium.\n\nSix minutes into the second half, Argentina scored again. A right-wing cross led to a scramble in the Canadian defense.\n\nEnzo Fern\u00e1ndez seized the moment and shot, with Messi redirecting the ball past the Canadian goalkeeper, notching his first goal in this Copa Am\u00e9rica.\n\nCopa Am\u00e9rica Highlights\n\nThis match mattered for several reasons. Firstly, Argentina, under Scaloni, seeks to solidify its dominance in South American football.\n\nIn addition, the victory highlighted their effective team dynamics and the strategic prowess of their coach.\n\nMessi's goal was significant, demonstrating his enduring influence on the field and his vital role in Argentina's campaign.\n\nCanada's performance was remarkable, reaching the semifinals against more experienced teams. Their progress in this tournament showcased their growing strength in international football.\n\nThe third-place match against either Uruguay or Colombia will be a chance for Canada to further prove their capabilities.\n\nIn a larger context, this Copa Am\u00e9rica has been pivotal for Argentina's ambition and Canada's emerging potential in the football world.\n\nArgentina's victory set the stage {"uri": "8218200257", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:20:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:20:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:19:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/sports/lionel-messi-says-he-will-keep-on-playing-for-argentina-beyond-copa-america-final/articleshow/111627162.cms", "title": "Lionel Messi says he will keep on playing for Argentina beyond Copa America final", "body": "After scoring his 109th international goal, Lionel Messi expressed his intention to continue living day by day without worrying about the future, despite being 37 years old. Teammate Angel Di Maria, with 31 goals in 144 appearances, announced his retirement after Sunday's game, leaving an impressive legacy in Argentine football. Coach Lionel Scaloni hopes Di Maria will reconsider, as World Cup qualifying resumes in September and the 2026 final approaches at MetLife Stadium.\"As I've said before, I intend to continue,\" he said Tuesday night after Argentina's 2-0 win over Canada. \"I intend to keep living day by day without thinking about what will come in the future or whether I'll continue or not. It's something I just live each day. I'm 37 years and only God knows when the end will be.\"\n\nMessi scored his 109th international goal, his first in this year's tournament. It was his 14th in Copa America play, three shy of the record.\n\nThe eight-time Ballon d'Or winner spoke outside the locker room at MetLife Stadium, where he announced his retirement after missing a penalty kick in the shootout loss to Chile in the 2016 Copa America final. He reversed his decision seven weeks later and has scored 54 goals in 73 international appearances since, raising his matches for Argentina to 186 as he helped win the 2021 Copa America and 2022 World Cup.\n\nTeammate Angel Di Maria does intend to retire after Sunday's game against Uruguay or Colombia at Miami Gardens, Florida. The 36-year-old Di Maria made his international debut in 2008 and has 31 goals in 144 appearances,\n\n\"It's my last battle. There's nothing left to say that I haven't said a lot of times before,\" Di Maria explained. \"It's my last game. I have to say thank you to all Argentineans and to this generation that has allowed me to lift so many trophies.\"\n\nDi Maria joined with Messi to lead Argentina to it's third World Cup and 15th Copa America title.\n\n\"We've enjoyed him so much,\" Messi said. \"He's always given his all and the best of himself and that he will retire in a final is something he simply deserves.\"\n\nArgentina coach Lionel Scaloni held out hope Di Maria will reverse his decision.\n\n\"We don't want to start crying right now. We don't want to feel melancholy,\" Scaloni said. \"We have to let him play and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us.\"\n\nSouth American World Cup qualifying resumes in September, with each national team scheduled to play 12 more matches. The 2026 World Cup final will be at MetLife, that July 19.\n\n\"We will never be the ones to close the door,\" Scaloni said. \"He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great. {"uri": "8218199000", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:19:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:19:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:18:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/soccer-messi-on-target-as-argentina-beat-canada-2-0-to-reach-copa-america-final/2167895/", "title": "Soccer-Messi on target as Argentina beat Canada 2-0 to reach Copa America final", "body": "\"Let's enjoy what we are experiencing as a national team, as a group. It is not easy to be in a final again, to compete again to be champions,\" Messi told TyC Sports.\n\n\"I'm living it as I have been living everything lately: enjoying it very much and being aware, as it happens to Fideo (Di Maria) and Ota (Otamendi), that these are the last battles.\"\n\nArgentina have won a joint-record 15 Copa titles and reached the final six times in the past eight editions but Canada caused them real problems in the opening 20 minutes, Jacob Shaffelburg twice shooting wide from promising positions.\n\nAfter soaking up the early pressure, though, Argentina went ahead when Rodrigo De Paul played through Alvarez, who ghosted in between two defenders to score with a tidy finish in the 22nd minute.\n\nArgentina, 2022 World Cup winners and number one in FIFA's rankings, gradually took control and Messi had a chance to double their lead in the 44th minute when he created space in the box with some silky footwork before lashing his effort wide.\n\nCanada nearly snatched an equaliser against the run of play in first-half stoppage time as Jonathan David sneaked in ahead of his marker to get on the end of a long throw, but his close-range shot was hit straight at goalkeeper Emiliano Martinez.\n\nMessi had struggled with a muscle injury earlier in the tournament but appeared revitalised on a hot and humid evening at the MetLife Stadium.\n\nHe scored Argentina's second in the 51st minute, sticking out a boot to divert Enzo Fernandez's shot from the edge of the area past Canada goalkeeper Maxime Crepeau.\n\nThe goal moved Messi to joint fifth in the all-time Copa America scoring charts, level with Peru's Paolo Guerrero and Chile's Eduardo Vargas, on 14.\n\nHis 109th goal for Argentina also saw him surpass Iran's Ali Daei to take sole possession of second place on the all-time international scoring charts. Messi trails only Cristiano Ronaldo, who has scored 130 goals for Portugal.\n\nDespite their two-goal cushion, Argentina had a nervy finish to the match as Canada substitute Tani Oluwaseyi tested Martinez with a crisp shot in the 89th minute before directing a glancing header wide a minute later.\n\nFor Canada, the defeat ends a remarkable run in which they defied expectations and performed better than their higher-ranked CONCACAF rivals Mexico and the United States, their fellow co-hosts of the 2026 World Cup.\n\n\"They're the best team in the world, but at the same time we had our chances in the beginning of the game,\" midfielder Stephen Eustaquio told Canadian broadcaster TSN.\n\n\"If we scored one of our chances, the story of the game would probably have been different. To get here, the last four of the Copa America, it's a big achievement.\"\n\n(Reporting by Aadi Nair in Bengaluru, additional reporting by Field Level Media; Editing by Peter Rutherford)", "source": {"uri": "8217981713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:19:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:19:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:19:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Soccer/496416/Argentina-shows-its-class-in-2-0-win-over-gutsy-Canada-in-Copa-America-semifinal", "title": "Argentina shows its class in 2-0 win over gutsy Canada in Copa America semifinal - Soccer", "body": "Goals by Lionel Messi and Julian Alvarez lifted top-ranked Argentina past Canada as the star-studded South American side showed its pedigree in a 2-0 win in the Copa America semifinal on Tuesday.\n\nDespite the loss, the 48th-ranked Canadians did not disappoint before a lively crowd of 80,102 on a hot, humid night at MetLife Stadium, home of the NFL's New York Giants and Jets, as well as the venue for the 2026 FIFA World Cup final.\n\nThe loud crowd was largely clad in Argentina blue although there were pockets of red. They saw a gutsy performance from Canada, albeit one lacking in clinical finishing, and pure class from Argentina, whose passing and buildup were straight out of a video game at times.\n\nThe Canadians also fell 2-0 to Argentina when they met in the June 20th tournament opener in Atlanta. Argentina thumped Canada 5-0 in their only other meeting, in May 2010 in Buenos Aires in the Argentines' final warm-up before the FIFA World Cup in South Africa.\n\nMessi and the Argentines will play either No. 12 Colombia or No. 14 Uruguay, who meet Wednesday in Charlotte, N.C., in Sunday's championship game at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla.\n\n\"It's insane what this team has done, what the Argentina national team is doing,\" Messi said. \"For those who remain from the old guard, it's beyond impressive that the national team is in another final.\"\n\nCanada heads to Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte for Saturday's third-place game.\n\nArgentina showed its quality, content to stroke the ball around and then change gears in an instant when it saw an opening in Canada's defence.\n\nAnd despite a positive start, Canada fell behind in the 22nd minute on Argentina's first shot on target. The Canadian defence was carved open by a long pass from Rodrigo De Paul that Alvarez controlled with a fine first touch before outmuscling Moise Bombito and slipping a shot through goalkeeper Max Crepeau's legs.\n\nCoach Jesse Marsch and the Canadian bench were irate, believing a foul by Argentina's Nicol\u00e1s Tagliafico -- who steamrollered Richie Laryea as he tried to corral Crepeau's goal kick, allowing the South Americans to win possession -- had been missed before the goal. Eight touches later the ball was in the Canada net.\n\nBut Chilean referee Piero Maza was letting the teams play, much to Marsch's displeasure. The Canada coach eventually received a caution in the 77th minute for voicing his displeasure with the officiating.\n\nMessi made it 2-0 in the 51st minute with a slight redirect of an Enzo Fernandez shot through traffic after Canada failed to clear the ball. Canada had eight defenders in front of Crepeau in its penalty box but could not snuff out the threat.\n\nThe goal survived a video review check for offside with Messi getting the green light for his first goal of the tournament and his 14th in career Copa America play.\n\nCanada captain Alphonso Davies had to leave in the 71st minute after being injured in a hard tackle by Gonzalo Montiel that went unpunished.\n\nThere was some bad blood late in the game, with Argentina upset at Canadian midfielder Ismael Kone petulantly kicking the ball into one of their fallen players.\n\nMetLife Stadium's temporary grass surface appeared heavy, with water splashing and sand popping up during dribbles.\n\n\"It's has been a very difficult Copa America, very competitive, bad surfaces, excessive heat,\" Messi said.\n\nThe Canadian men were looking to reach their first tournament final since the 2000 Gold Cup when they upset Colombia to win the CONCACAF crown.\n\nCanada, the last survivor of the six CONCACAF guest teams, is making its Copa debut. The Canadian men beat No. 99 Trinidad and Tobago 2-1 in a March playoff to make the 16-country field -- as the 11th-ranked team at the tournament.\n\nIt has been an eventful competition for the Canadian side under Marsch, the 50-year-old American who has infused his new team with youth and confidence as well as a new skipper in Davies.\n\nCrepeau has established himself as Canada's No. 1 goalkeeper. Bombito and Derek Cornelius have become the heart of the defence while speedy winger Jacob Shaffelburg has had a breakout tournament.\n\nThere have been challenges.\n\nBombito was the victim of online racial abuse after a hard tackle on Messi in the tournament opener. And winger Tajon Buchan broke his leg in training.\n\nMarsch made just one change to the starting 11 that beat Venezuela with Kone who scored the decisive penalty in the shootout after coming in on off the bench, slotting in for Jonathan Osorio.\n\nCanada looked to restrict the Argentines with its press from the get-go, coming forward with two early counterattacks that saw Shaffelburg fire shots off-target.\n\nMessi shot just wide in the 11th minute on an Argentine counterattack. And the ever-dangerous Argentina captain just missed again with a low shot late in the first half, followed by an attempted chip over Crepeau in stoppage time.\n\nArgentina 'keeper Emiliano Mart\u00ednez, sporting an Argentina flag dyed into the side of his hair, was called into action in the dying seconds of the half after Jonathan David got to an Alistair Johnston long throw-in, poking the ball toward goal from close range.\n\nFor the second game in a row, Argentina kept Canada waiting to start the second half. After Canada went down 2-0, Crepeau was called into action again to stop Alvarez.\n\nAli Ahmed, Liam Millar, Tani Oluwaseyi, Mathieu Choiniere and Osorio came on for Canada in the second half. The subs helped spark the offence with Canada threatening the South Americans as the clock wound down.\n\nOluwaseyi had two good chances in the dying minutes, with an acrobatic Martinez managing to get his body in front of the first shot in the 89th minute. The Canadian sub then saw his header just go wide.\n\nArgentina came into the semifinal having lost just once in 18 games (16-1-1) since defeating France via penalty shootout in the World Cup final in December 2022. The one loss during that run was a 2-0 defeat at the hands of Uruguay in World Cup qualifying in November. And the draw turned into the penalty shootout win over No. 30 Ecuador last time out.\n\nThat didn't deter Canadian rapper Drake from placing a $300,000 bet on Canada to win, a wager returning $2.88 million if successful. Drake posted the betting slip online, as he often does with his wagers.\n\nAfter losing to Argentina in the tournament opener, Canada beat No. 31 Peru 1-0 and tied No. 40 Chile 0-0 to finish second in Group A behind the Argentines. The Canadians then beat No. 54 Venezuela in a penalty shootout in the quarterfinal.\n\nArgentina is seeking its third major crown after the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup. The Argentines are tied with Uruguay for most Copa America titles with 15.", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Argentina captain hints at 'last battles'", "body": "Whether this is truly Lionel Messi's final international hurrah remains to be seen. Nevertheless, his leadership and on-field brilliance have cemented his place as one of the greatest footballers of all time.\n\nLionel Messi, Argentina's iconic captain, has hinted at an impending international retirement after leading his team to another Copa America final. Argentina secured their place in the championship match with a convincing 2-0 victory over Canada on Tuesday.\n\nFollowing the win, Lionel Messi spoke to DSports Radio, acknowledging the twilight of his international career. \"Yes, I am aware that these are the last battles,\" he said. \"I am enjoying them to the fullest.\"\n\n\"It's not easy to be in a final again, we need to enjoy, enjoy every moment,\" he added, emphasizing the importance of cherishing this potentially final stage.\n\nThis victory marks Argentina's third consecutive major final appearance. They emerged victorious in the 2021 Copa America and the 2022 World Cup, solidifying their position as a dominant force in international football.\n\nLionel Messi himself opened his scoring account in this year's Copa America with a goal in the semifinal. This strike not only propelled Argentina towards victory but also propelled him past Iranian legend Ali Daei to become the second-highest international goal scorer of all time, with only Cristiano Ronaldo ahead of him.\n\nArgentina will face the winner of Wednesday's match between Uruguay and Colombia in the final on Sunday. A win would not only secure their second consecutive Copa America title but also etch their name in history as the team with the most Copa America titles (30).\n\nWhether this is truly Lionel Messi's final international hurrah remains to be seen. Nevertheless, his leadership and on-field brilliance have cemented his place as one of the greatest footballers of all time. {"uri": "8217990905", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:30:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:30:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:26:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13618557/No-bed-roses-Scaloni-hails-Argentinas-grit-making-Copa-final.html", "title": "No bed of roses: Scaloni hails Argentina's grit after making Copa...", "body": "EAST RUTHERFORD, New Jersey, July 9 (Reuters) - A rgentina's path to the Copa America final has been no bed of roses, coach Lionel Scaloni said, as he lauded his players for their performance in Tuesday's 2-0 semi-final win over Canada.\n\nCanada, ranked 48th in the world, played high-energy football and looked to turn the match into a physical battle but Argentina's quality shone through in the end.\n\nJulian Alvarez and Lionel Messi scored to secure Argentina's spot in the final of a third straight major tournament after their victories at the 2022 World Cup and Copa America in 2021.\n\n\"It is extremely tough to reach another final. It is tough because we know how hard it is to get there,\" Scaloni told reporters.\n\n\"The bar has been set very high. Everyone thought it was going to be a bed of roses and it wasn't like that at all. Canada proved it today by being a very difficult opponent.\"\n\nThis edition of the Copa America is likely to represent the last chance for many senior squad members to add to their trophy collection with the national team.\n\nAngel di Maria, 36, said last year he would retire from international football after the Copa America, while Messi, 37, and Nicolas Otamendi, 36, are both nearing the end of their careers.\n\n\"You know how I feel about Angel. We don't want to retire him earlier than needed,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"We don't want to feel melancholy. We have to let him play, and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us. But so far, he's here, and he has to be allowed to enjoy this moment.\n\n\"For Leo (Messi), it's similar to Angel. We have to let him be and we will never be the ones to close the door. He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great.\"\n\nIn Sunday's final, Argentina could face either Uruguay, who beat them in a World Cup qualifier in November, or Colombia, who are on a 27-match unbeaten run under coach Nestor Lorenzo.\n\n\"These two potential opponents are top-notch national teams, but it would be reckless to say that I prefer one or the other,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"One of them already beat us. It was a very tough match. We have not played against Colombia with this coach, but we know it could be very difficult as well.\"\n\n(Reporting by Aadi Nair in Bengaluru; Editing by Peter Rutherford )", "source": {"uri": Canada's attempt at a resurgence in the second half was dealt a major blow when Messi took centre stage and scored in the 51st minute.\n\nThe goal not only put an end to Canada's chances of scripting a fightback but also helped Messi become only the second player to score goals in six editions of the CONMEBOL Copa Am\u00e9rica alongside Zizinho of Brazil.\n\nOther than 2024, Messi scored in the 2007, 2015, 2016, 2019 and 2021 editions of the tournament. On the other hand, Zizinho scored in the six editions of the prestigious tournament held between 1942 and 1957.\n\nThe 2011 edition was the only forgettable outing for Messi as he couldn't score a goal in the entire tournament and Argentina had also failed to secure a semifinal berth.\n\nMessi's goal also helped him move past Ali Daei to become the second-leading goal scorer in the history of international football. Messi has scored 109 goals in an Argentina jersey - one more than Iran's Daei.\n\nMessi has moved closer to Cristiano Ronaldo who is the leading goal scorer in international football history.\n\nMeanwhile, the second semifinal of the tournament will be played between Uruguay and a spirited Colombian side at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina.", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-416918982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "04:15:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T04:15:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:15:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://keralakaumudi.com/en/news/news.php?id=1341496&u=", "title": "Argentina beats Canada in semi-finals and enters Copa America finals", "body": "NEW YORK: Defending champions Argentina reached the finals of the Copa America tournament after defeating Canada by two goals. Julian Alvarez and Lionel Messi scored for Argentina. Argentina will face the winners of the Uruguay-Colombia match in the final on July 15.\n\nJulian Alvarez scored in the first half and Lionel Messi scored in the second half of the match held at the MetLife Stadium in New York. This is Messi's first goal of the tournament and Alvarez' second.\n\nArgentina has reached the semi-finals after defeating Ecuador in the penalty shootout in the quarter thanks to goalkeeper Amy Martinez. Canada defeated Venezuela in a penalty shootout to advance to the quarterfinals. {"uri": "2024-07-417409195", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:20:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:20:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T04:18:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/sports/soccer/no-bed-roses-scaloni-hails-argentinas-grit-after-making-copa-final-2024-07-10/", "title": "No bed of roses: Scaloni hails Argentina's grit after making Copa final", "body": "EAST RUTHERFORD, New Jersey, July 9 (Reuters) - Argentina's path to the Copa America final has been no bed of roses, coach Lionel Scaloni said, as he lauded his players for their performance in Tuesday's 2-0 semi-final win over Canada.\n\nCanada, ranked 48th in the world, played high-energy football and looked to turn the match into a physical battle but Argentina's quality shone through in the end.\n\nJulian Alvarez and Lionel Messi scored to secure Argentina's spot in the final of a third straight major tournament after their victories at the 2022 World Cup and Copa America in 2021.\n\n\"It is extremely tough to reach another final. It is tough because we know how hard it is to get there,\" Scaloni told reporters.\n\n\"The bar has been set very high. Everyone thought it was going to be a bed of roses and it wasn't like that at all. Canada proved it today by being a very difficult opponent.\"\n\nThis edition of the Copa America is likely to represent the last chance for many senior squad members to add to their trophy collection with the national team.\n\nAngel di Maria, 36, said last year he would retire from international football after the Copa America, while Messi, 37, and Nicolas Otamendi, 36, are both nearing the end of their careers.\n\n\"You know how I feel about Angel. We don't want to retire him earlier than needed,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"We don't want to feel melancholy. We have to let him play, and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us. But so far, he's here, and he has to be allowed to enjoy this moment.\n\n\"For Leo (Messi), it's similar to Angel. We have to let him be and we will never be the ones to close the door. He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great.\"\n\nIn Sunday's final, Argentina could face either Uruguay, who beat them in a World Cup qualifier in November, or Colombia, who are on a 27-match unbeaten run under coach Nestor Lorenzo.\n\n\"These two potential opponents are top-notch national teams, but it would be reckless to say that I prefer one or the other,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"One of them already beat us. It was a very tough match. We have not played against Colombia with this coach, but we know it could be very difficult as well.\"\n\nReporting by Aadi Nair in Bengaluru; Editing by Peter Rutherford", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-417813492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "18:41:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T18:41:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T17:57:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.kansascity.com/sports/copa-america/article289930994.html", "title": "Copa America: Victory on Independence Day, a date for celebration", "body": "July 9th is an important national holiday in Argentina, the equivalent to our July 4th, as it is also their Independence Day. The biggest avenue in Argentina is also called 'Avenida 9 de Julio' commemorating the day year-round for the millions who traverse it.\n\nWith seven lanes going in each direction, it is also the widest avenue in the world. While not as grand, yesterday's Argentine victory on that same date over Canada that leads them once again to the Copa America finals, was more cause for celebration on an already festive day.\n\nThe Argentinian National team delivered a repeat performance besting Canada by the same score as they did in the opening tournament match 2-0, while Julian Alvarez did a repeat by scoring goals in both games.\n\nWhile the defending champions celebrated in style in Miami, the current home of Lionel Messi, Canada still looks to compete for third place on Saturday against whichever team comes up short tonight between Colombia and Uruguay. A chance for third place and coming in at least at number 4, is not too bad for a Canadian team finishing their first participation in Copa America and going further than its 5 fellow Concacaf national teams including the United States and Mexico.\n\nMessi finally celebrated a goal in this Copa America after four matches when he scored at MetLife Stadium in the 51st minute.\n\nThe Argentine captain, who already has 14 goals including those in previous editions of the tournament, became the second player to score in six different Copa Americas, tying the record of Brazilian Zizinho, who did so between 1942 and 1957.\n\nJulian Alvarez's goal off a pass from Rodrigo de Paul gave Argentina the lead against Canada in the 23rd minute for his second Copa America goal.\n\nBoth of Alvarez's goals have come against the 'Maple Leafs', the one before was the first goal of the entire tournament during the 2-0 win in the opening match.\n\nAlphonso Davies, captain and star of the Canadian national team, hurt his right ankle after a hard collision with Gonzalo Montiel and was replaced in minute 71, by Jonathan Osorio.\n\nThe left-back tried to return to the field after being treated by Canada's medical services; however, he was unable to do so and came off as a substitute.\n\nCanada tried to beat Argentina, in its first participation in a Copa Am\u00e9rica in which it ended up being the best CONCACAF national team during this tournament.\n\nThe team led by Jesse Marsch wants to culminate its historic performance by taking third place in Copa America next Saturday when they will {"uri": "8218198998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "07:19:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T07:19:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T07:18:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/soccer-no-bed-of-roses-scaloni-hails-argentinas-grit-after-making-copa-final/2168000/", "title": "Soccer-No bed of roses: Scaloni hails Argentina's grit after making Copa final", "body": "Julian Alvarez and Lionel Messi scored to secure Argentina's spot in the final of a third straight major tournament after their victories at the 2022 World Cup and Copa America in 2021.\n\n\"It is extremely tough to reach another final. It is tough because we know how hard it is to get there,\" Scaloni told reporters.\n\n\"The bar has been set very high. Everyone thought it was going to be a bed of roses and it wasn't like that at all. Canada proved it today by being a very difficult opponent.\"\n\nThis edition of the Copa America is likely to represent the last chance for many senior squad members to add to their trophy collection with the national team.\n\nAngel di Maria, 36, said last year he would retire from international football after the Copa America, while Messi, 37, and Nicolas Otamendi, 36, are both nearing the end of their careers.\n\n\"You know how I feel about Angel. We don't want to retire him earlier than needed,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"We don't want to feel melancholy. We have to let him play, and then we'll see if we can convince him or not to stay with us. But so far, he's here, and he has to be allowed to enjoy this moment.\n\n\"For Leo (Messi), it's similar to Angel. We have to let him be and we will never be the ones to close the door. He can be with our team for as long as he wants to be. And if he wants to retire but still come and hang around, it would be great.\"\n\nIn Sunday's final, Argentina could face either Uruguay, who beat them in a World Cup qualifier in November, or Colombia, who are on a 27-match unbeaten run under coach Nestor Lorenzo.\n\n\"These two potential opponents are top-notch national teams, but it would be reckless to say that I prefer one or the other,\" Scaloni said.\n\n\"One of them already beat us. It was a very tough match.
